{
  "article_text": [
    "a compelling motivation for accurate computations of the gravitational radiation field generated by compact binary systems ( _ i.e. _ , made of neutron stars and/or black holes ) is the need for accurate",
    "_ templates _ to be used in the data analysis of the current and future generations of laser interferometric gravitational wave detectors .",
    "it is indeed recognized that the _ inspiral _ phase of the coalescence of two compact objects represents an extremely important source for the ground - based detectors ligo / virgo , provided that their total mass does not exceed say 10 or 20 @xmath6 ( this includes the interesting case of double neutron - star systems ) , and for space - based detectors like lisa , in the case of the coalescence of two galactic black holes , if the masses are within the range between say @xmath7 and @xmath8 .    for these sources",
    "the _ post - newtonian _ ( pn ) approximation scheme has proved to be the appropriate theoretical tool in order to construct the necessary templates .",
    "a program started long ago with the goal of obtaining these templates with 3pn and even 3.5pn accuracy.pn for a term in the wave form or ( for instance ) the energy flux which is of the order of @xmath9 relatively to the lowest - order newtonian quadrupolar radiation .",
    "] several studies @xcite have shown that such a high pn precision is probably sufficient , not only for detecting the signals in ligo / virgo , but also for analyzing them and accurately measuring the parameters of the binary ( such high - accuracy templates will also be of great value for detecting massive black - hole mergers in lisa ) . the templates have been first completed through 2.5pn order , for both the phase @xcite and wave amplitude @xcite . the 3.5pn accuracy for the templates ( in the case where the compact objects have negligible intrinsic spins ) has been achieved more recently , in essentially two steps .    1 .   the first step has been to compute all the terms , in both the 3pn equations of motion , either in hamiltonian form @xcite or using harmonic coordinates @xcite , and the 3.5pn gravitational radiation field , using a multipolar wave generation formalism @xcite , by means of the hadamard self - field regularization @xcite , in short hr .",
    "( the 3.5pn terms in the equations of motion have been added in refs .",
    "however , a few terms were left undetermined by hadamard s regularization , which corresponds to some incompleteness of this regularization occurring at the 3pn order .",
    "these terms could be parametrized by some unknown numerical coefficients called _",
    "ambiguity parameters_. 2 .",
    "the second step has been to fix the values of the ambiguity parameters by means of dimensional regularization @xcite , henceforth abbreviated as dr .",
    "technically , dr is based on analytic continuation in the dimension of space @xmath10 .",
    "the ambiguity parameter @xmath11 entering the 3pn equations of motion has been computed in refs .",
    "@xcite , with result @xmath12 .",
    "( this result has also been obtained with an alternative approach in refs .",
    "the three ambiguity parameters appearing in the 3pn gravitational radiation field will be shown in the present paper to have the following unique values @xmath13 as already announced in ref .",
    "the method we use for applying dr essentially consists in computing the _ difference _ between dr and some appropriately defined hadamard - type regularization called below the pure - hadamard - schwartz ( phs ) regularization .",
    "those results complete the determination of the 3.5pn - accurate phase evolution as it suffices to insert into the formulas of ref .",
    "@xcite the value for @xmath11 , together with the values given by ( [ xikappazeta ] ) .",
    "actually , this phase evolution depends only on @xmath11 and on the following particular combination of parameters , @xmath14 the present paper is devoted to the details of our dr computation of the ambiguity parameters , _ item _ ( 2 ) above , which has led to the values ( [ xikappazeta])([theta ] ) .",
    "we refer to @xcite for a summary of our method and a general discussion .",
    "let us emphasize that the values ( [ xikappazeta ] ) , which constitute the end result of the application of dr , have all been confirmed by alternative methods .",
    "our first independent check has been the confirmation of one particular combination of the ambiguity parameters , namely @xmath15 , which was shown to follow from the requirement that the 3pn mass dipole moment of the binary , computed in @xcite from the multipolar wave generation formalism , should agree with the 3pn center - of - mass position , known from the conservative part of the 3pn equations of motion in harmonic coordinates @xcite .",
    "secondly , we have also obtained the value of @xmath5 by considering the limiting physical situation of a _ boosted schwarzschild solution _ , corresponding to the case where the mass of one of the particles is exactly zero , and the other particle moves with uniform velocity @xcite .",
    "it can be argued from this calculation that the value of @xmath5 in eq .",
    "( [ xikappazeta ] ) is a consequence of the global poincar invariance of the multipolar wave generation formalism .",
    "thirdly , in sec .  [ secvii ] below , we shall be able to show that the value of @xmath4 is zero by a diagrammatic approach ( where the `` diagrams '' are taken in the sense of @xcite ) , showing that no dangerously divergent diagrams contributing to @xmath4 appear at this order .",
    "those checks altogether provide a confirmation , _ independent from dr _ , for all the parameters ( [ xikappazeta ] ) .",
    "the plan of this paper is as follows . in section  [ secii ]",
    "we investigate the symmetric - trace - free ( stf ) multipole decomposition in @xmath0 dimensions for a scalar field with compact - support source . in section  [ seciii ]",
    "we generalize to @xmath0 dimensions the known results for the multipole expansion of the gravitational field and the definition of the source - type multipole moments .",
    "section  [ seciv ] is devoted to the explicit expressions of the source terms in the latter source multipole moments at the 3pn order in terms of a convenient set of retarded - like elementary potentials .",
    "then , in section  [ secv ] , we obtain a general formula for the difference between dr and hr ( in the phs variant of it ) .",
    "this difference is non - zero at the 3pn order because of the occurrence of poles in @xmath0 dimensions ( _ i.e. _ , @xmath16 ) . in section  [ secvi ]",
    "we deduce the ambiguity parameters from the dr regularization of the 3pn mass quadrupole moment , and we check that the 3pn mass dipole is in agreement with the known center - of - mass position deduced from the equations of motion . section  [ secvii ] deals with a direct computation of the pole part of the moments using diagrams , their renormalization using shifts of the world - lines , and the check that @xmath17 .",
    "in section  [ secviii ] we present an alternative derivation of the value of @xmath5 based on considering the physical situation of a single _ boosted _ point particle in @xmath0 dimensions ( the result agrees with the recent computation of the boosted schwarzschild solution in @xcite ) .",
    "a crucial input for the derivations we are going to perform in the present article is the multipolar expansion of solutions of flat space - time wave equations in @xmath18 dimensions .",
    "we denote by @xmath19 the flat dalembertian operator , using the signature `` mostly plus '' , _",
    "i.e. _ , @xmath20 , where @xmath21 and @xmath22 is the laplace operator .",
    "we first consider the case of a scalar wave equation , say @xmath23 and shall postpone to sec .",
    "[ seciii ] the case of tensorial wave equations .",
    "note that , in the present work , we shall not introduce any numerical factor in the `` source '' @xmath24 on the right hand side ( rhs ) of the inhomogeneous scalar wave equation ( [ boxphi ] ) .",
    "similarly , we define the scalar green functions as the solutions of @xmath25 where @xmath26 is a @xmath0-dimensional dirac distribution , such that @xmath27 .",
    "when @xmath28 , the _ retarded _ green function takes the simple form @xmath29 because of the presence of the factor @xmath30 in ( [ green2 ] ) , it was convenient , when working in @xmath31 dimensions , to introduce a factor @xmath32 in front of the rhs s of ( [ boxphi ] ) and ( [ green1 ] ) .",
    "however , there is no analogous , universally simplifying factor in @xmath33 dimensions , so it is finally simpler to introduce no factors at all in ( [ boxphi])([green1 ] ) .",
    "the @xmath33-dimensional retarded green function has no simple expression in @xmath34 space .",
    "however , starting from its well - known fourier - space expression , one can write the following simple integral expression ( see _ e.g. _ @xcite ) , @xmath35 notice that this is in fact a function of @xmath36 and @xmath37 only : say @xmath38 . here",
    "@xmath39 is the heaviside step function , and @xmath40 the usual bessel function .",
    "actually , we shall never need to use the explicit form ( [ green3 ] ) of the green function in @xmath33 dimensions .",
    "indeed , we shall obtain the @xmath0-dimensional generalizations of the @xmath41-dimensional _ relativistic multipole moments _ , obtained in refs .",
    "@xcite , by working directly with the source @xmath24 of the wave equation ( [ boxphi ] ) , or of its tensor generalizations . to do this , we note first that the retarded solution of ( [ boxphi ] ) reads @xmath42    in this section , we shall consider sources @xmath43 having a _ spatially compact _ support in @xmath0 space dimensions : say @xmath44 when @xmath45 , where @xmath46 is the source s radius .",
    "we are interested in the _ multipolar expansion _ of the field @xmath47 , _ i.e. _ , its decomposition ( when considered in the external domain @xmath45 ) in @xmath0-dimensional spherical harmonics . traditionally , the multipolar expansion of @xmath47 , eq .",
    "( [ sol1 ] ) , is obtained by expanding the spatial kernel @xmath48 in powers of @xmath49 .",
    "this introduces the ( reducible ) multipole moments of the source , say @xmath50 .",
    "a simpler , formally equivalent way of proceeding is to replace the continuous source @xmath51 by its `` _ _ distributional skeleton _ _ '' , _",
    "i.e. _ , an expansion in increasing derivatives of the @xmath0-dimensional dirac distribution @xmath52 .",
    "[ for notational simplicity , we henceforth suppress the superscript @xmath53 on @xmath52 . ]",
    "this skeletonized version of the source @xmath24 is equivalent to a continuous function @xmath51 with compact support when ( and only when ) it is integrated by a regular kernel @xmath54 , as in ( [ sol1 ] ) .",
    "it reads @xmath55 where the coefficients are the reducible multipole moments @xmath56 we recall our simplified notation : @xmath57 denotes a multi - index @xmath58 and we use the shorthands @xmath59 , where @xmath60 , and @xmath61 , where @xmath62",
    ".    the skeleton expansion ( [ sskel ] ) does not yet give rise to a multipole expansion because the various terms on the rhs of ( [ sskel ] ) do not correspond to _ irreducible _ representations of the @xmath0-dimensional rotation group @xmath63 .",
    "however , it is relatively simple to transform the expansion ( [ sskel ] ) into irreducible components .",
    "to do this , it is enough to decompose the symmetric tensors @xmath64 into irreducible symmetric and trace - free ( stf ) pieces , which is easily done by using the stf decomposition of @xmath65 in @xmath0 dimensions , obtained by recursively separating the traces , like in @xmath66 .",
    "here we denote the stf projection by means of a hat : @xmath67 $ ] , or sometimes by means of brackets surrounding the indices : @xmath68 .",
    "the general formula defined by this recursion has already been given in ref .",
    "@xcite dimensions . ] and reads    [ yl ] @xmath69}\\,a_\\ell^k\\,\\delta_{\\{i_1i_2 } \\cdots \\delta_{i_{2k-1}i_{2k}}\\,\\widehat{y}_{l -2k\\}}\\ ,",
    "\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert^{2k},\\\\ \\text{with}\\quad a_\\ell^k&\\equiv&\\frac{1}{2^k}\\frac{\\gamma\\left(\\frac{d}{2}+ \\ell-2k\\right)}{\\gamma\\left(\\frac{d}{2}+\\ell - k\\right)}\\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    here , @xmath70 is the kronecker symbol , @xmath71 $ ] denotes the integer part of @xmath72 , @xmath73 is a multi - index with @xmath74 indices , and @xmath75 is the usual eulerian function .",
    "the curly brackets surrounding the indices refer to the ( unnormalized , minimal ) sum of the permutations of the indices which keep the object fully symmetric in @xmath57 , for instance @xmath76 ( for convenience we do not normalize the latter sum ) .",
    "we replace the stf decomposition ( [ yl ] ) into ( [ sl ] ) and insert the resulting moments back into eq .",
    "( [ sskel ] ) . after some simple manipulations we arrive at    [ smult1]@xmath77,\\\\ \\text{where}\\quad \\alpha_\\ell^k&\\equiv&\\frac{1}{2^{2k}k!}\\frac{\\gamma\\left(\\frac{d}{2}+ \\ell\\right)}{\\gamma\\left(\\frac{d}{2}+\\ell+k\\right)}\\ , .",
    "\\label{smult1b}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    at this point let us notice that any term in the skeletonized source @xmath78 which is in the form of a dalembert operator @xmath79 acting on spatial gradients or time derivatives of the delta function , say @xmath80 $ ] , symbolizes any product of space or time derivatives ( so that , for instance , @xmath81 can involve any power of the box operator @xmath79 itself ) ] will give no contribution to the multipole expansion of @xmath47 .",
    "indeed , a term in the source of the form @xmath82 $ ] , with @xmath83 , @xmath84 , will yield a contribution to the solution of the form @xmath85\\right ) = \\box^{i } \\left[f(t)\\,\\partial_l\\delta(\\mathbf{x})\\right]$ ] .",
    "such a contribution is localized at the spatial origin @xmath86 and thus vanishes outside of the world tube @xmath87 containing the source .",

    "as we just said , these terms will not contribute to the multipole expansion of the field @xmath47 , _ i.e. _ , considered in the external domain @xmath92 .    the most useful result for our purpose is the explicit expression of the stf moments in eq .",

    "henceforth we shall denote by @xmath116 the multipolar expansion of @xmath117 , which is therefore given by @xmath118 since the terms @xmath119 give zero when considered outside the compact support of the source . in terms of the retarded green s function",
    "the latter formula becomes @xmath120.\\ ] ] note that , in view of the retarded nature of the green function @xmath121 , the integral is limited to @xmath122 , and even to @xmath123 with @xmath37 .",
    "equation ( [ phimultg ] ) generalizes what was the basic result for the multipolar expansion of a @xmath41-dimensional inhomogeneous wave equation @xmath124 , namely @xmath125 a common feature of the result ( [ phimultg3 ] ) and its @xmath0-dimensional generalization ( [ phimultg ] ) is that each `` multipolar wave '' of degree @xmath94 is obtained by an @xmath94-tuple differentiation , with respect to the spatial coordinates , of an elementary _ spherically symmetric _ ( _ i.e. _ , monopolar ) retarded solution ; indeed , as mentioned above @xmath121 depends only on @xmath126 and @xmath127 . in @xmath41 dimensions",
    "the elementary spherically symmetric retarded solutions admit a simple expression in terms of the multipole moments , namely @xmath128 .",
    "by contrast , the @xmath0-dimensional analogue of each elementary spherically symmetric solution is a more complicated non - local _ functional _ of @xmath129 , which involves an integral over its time argument : @xmath130 .",
    "this non - locality in time in the expression of @xmath117 in terms of @xmath131 comes in addition to the non - locality in time entering the exact definition ( [ sellcompact ] ) of the effective source term @xmath132 .",
    "the former non - locality is evidently related to the fact that the `` huygens principle '' holds only in @xmath28 , @xmath100 , @xmath133 , @xmath134 dimensions . in these special dimensions",
    ", the support of the retarded green function @xmath135 is concentrated on the past light cone @xmath136 . on the other hand , in other dimensions ( and notably in dimensionally - continued complex ones ) the support of the retarded green function @xmath135 extends over the interior of the past light cone : @xmath137 .",
    "the calculations of the 3.5pn templates , refs .",
    "@xcite , applied the general expressions of the relativistic multipole moments of refs .",
    "@xcite , which are themselves to be inserted into the ( 3-dimensional ) multipolar post - minkowskian ( mpm ) formalism of ref .",
    "let us sketch how one can , in principle , generalize this mpm formalism to arbitrary dimensions @xmath0 .",
    "the basic building blocks of the mpm formalism are :    1 .",
    "the parametrization of a general solution of the linearized vacuum einstein equations in harmonic coordinates , say @xmath138 , by means of several sequences of _ irreducible _ multipole moments ; 2 .   the definition of an integral operator , called @xmath139 , which produces , when it is applied to the non - linear effective mpm source @xmath140 appearing at the @xmath141 non - linear iteration , a particular non - linear solution , @xmath142 , of the inhomogeneous wave equation @xmath143 ; 3 .   the definition of a complementary homogeneous solution @xmath144 ( @xmath145 ) such that @xmath146 satisfies the harmonicity condition @xmath147 .    given these building blocks , the mpm formalism generates , by iteration , a general solution of the non - linear vacuum einstein equations as a formal power series , @xmath148 , this solution being parametrized by the arbitrary `` seed '' multipole moments entering the definition of the first approximation @xmath149",
    "we briefly indicate how the various building blocks can be generalized to arbitrary dimensions @xmath0 .",
    "we have in mind here an extension to generic integer dimensions @xmath150 , before defining a formal continuation to complex dimensions .",
    "[ we consider mainly larger dimensions @xmath150 because they exhibit generic @xmath0-dependent features , while lower integer dimensions , @xmath151 , exhibit special phenomena . ]    in the previous section we have discussed the multipole expansion of scalar fields , @xmath152 , in arbitrary @xmath0 .",
    "we have seen that the general ( retarded ) solution outside the source @xmath24 could be parametrized , in any @xmath0 , by a set of symmetric trace - free ( stf ) time - dependent tensors @xmath153 .",
    "the situation is somewhat more complicated for other fields , notably the spin-2 field @xmath138 relevant for gravity in any @xmath0 . as we shall discuss in the next subsection , the multipole moments needed in a generic @xmath150 to parametrize a general gravitational field are more complicated than what can be used in @xmath28 . in @xmath28",
    ", one can use two independent sets of stf tensors , say @xmath154 ( the `` mass multipole moments '' ) and @xmath64 ( the `` spin multipole moments '' ) . in a generic @xmath150 ,",
    "one has still the analogue of the mass multipole moments , _",
    "i.e. _ , stf tensors @xmath154 corresponding to a young tableau made of @xmath94 horizontal boxes ( ) .",
    "however , the spin multipole moments must be described by a mixed young tableau having one vertical column of two boxes and @xmath155 complementary horizontal ones  so that there are @xmath94 boxes on the upper horizontal row ( ) .",
    "in addition , one must introduce a third type of irreducible representation of the @xmath0-dimensional rotation group @xmath63 , namely a mixed young tableau having two vertical columns of two boxes and @xmath156 complementary horizontal ones ( ) . for instance , when @xmath157 , this new irreducible representation has the symmetry of a weyl tensor in @xmath0 dimensions : . as is well known , this representation does not occur in @xmath158 . however , all these technical complications will have little impact on what we will need to calculate here . indeed ,",
    "as discussed below , it will be enough for our purpose of unambiguously computing the 3pn - level gravitational radiation emission to deal with the simpler _ mass _ multipole moments @xmath154 , which admit a uniform treatment in any dimension @xmath0 ( actually we shall use a specific definition for what we call the source - type mass multipole moments and denote them by @xmath159 instead of @xmath154 ) .    let us turn to the generalization of the integral operator @xmath139 . in @xmath28 ,",
    "the precise definition of this operator was the following .",
    "consider a typical non - linear source generated by the mpm iteration , _ e.g. _",
    "@xmath160 , in which @xmath161 is represented by its multipole expansion .",
    "one formally assumes that the multipole expansion of @xmath162 $ ] contains a _",
    "finite _ number of multipoles .",
    "this ensures that the non - linear source @xmath163 is a finite sum of terms of the form @xmath164 , with angular factor @xmath165 , @xmath166 .",
    "we can further expand @xmath167 in powers of @xmath168 and get @xmath163 as a sum of terms @xmath169 .",
    "though this multipole expansion of @xmath163 is only physically relevant in the region outside the source , say @xmath170 , in the mpm formalism we always mathematically extend its definition ( by real , analytic continuation in @xmath126 ) down to @xmath171 .",
    "then this formal construction , @xmath172 , valid by real analytic continuation for any @xmath173 , is _ identified _ with the multipolar expansion , say @xmath174 , of the physical field @xmath175 . while the physical @xmath175 takes different expressions inside ( @xmath176 ) and outside ( @xmath170 ) the source , the object @xmath177 is mathematically defined everywhere ( except at @xmath171 ) by the same formal expression , but is physically correct only when @xmath170 ( see @xcite for the notation and further discussion ) .    to deal with the singular behavior near @xmath171 of the non - linear mpm source terms , _ e.g. _",
    "@xmath178 , one introduces a complex number @xmath179 and considers the action of the retarded green operator onto the product of the source by a `` regularization '' factor @xmath180 , say @xmath181.\\ ] ] the length scale @xmath182 represents an arbitrary dimensionful parameter serving the purpose of adimensionalizing the above regularization factor .",
    "it was shown in ref .",
    "@xcite that the integral @xmath183 , eq .",
    "( [ b1 ] ) , is convergent when the real part of @xmath179 is large enough , and that @xmath183 , considered as a function of the complex number @xmath179 , is a _",
    "meromorphic _ function of @xmath179 , which has in general ( simple ) poles at @xmath184 , happens to have no pole when @xmath185 , due to the particular structure of the quadratic - order interaction .",
    "] coming from the singular behavior of the integrand @xmath163 near @xmath171 .",
    "[ one formally assumes that the multipole moments are time - independent before some instant @xmath186 , and at the end of the calculation the limit @xmath187 is taken . ] therefore , the laurent expansion of @xmath183 , near @xmath184 , is of the form @xmath188 one then defines , when @xmath28 , the _ finite part _ at @xmath184 of @xmath189 , denoted @xmath190 , as the term @xmath191 in the laurent expansion of @xmath183 .",
    "one proves that @xmath191 satisfies the equation @xmath192 and uses it as the `` particular '' second - order contribution @xmath193 to the second - order metric @xmath194 .",
    "let us not spend time on the construction of the additional homogeneous contribution @xmath195 necessary to satisfy the harmonicity condition @xmath196 [ an example of construction of such contribution will be given in ( [ q1munu ] ) below ] .",
    "having so constructed ( in @xmath28 ) the second - order term in the mpm expansion of the external metric , @xmath197 , one continues the iteration by considering the next order inhomogeneous equation @xmath198 and introducing @xmath199 $ ] .",
    "the singular behavior near @xmath171 of @xmath200 is more complicated ( it contains logarithms of @xmath126 ) , and , as a consequence , one finds that @xmath201 is still meromorphic in the complex @xmath179 plane , but will contain _ double _ poles at @xmath184 .",
    "again , one defines @xmath202 as the coefficient of the zero - th power of @xmath179 in the laurent expansion of @xmath201 when @xmath185 .",
    "having recalled the definition and properties of the operation @xmath139 in the 3-dimensional mpm formalism , let us sketch what changes when working in @xmath0 dimensions .",
    "let us start with the `` seed '' linearized metric @xmath149 . as we see in eq .",
    "( [ phimult ] ) , and will see below with more details for the tensorial analogue of the scalar multipole expansion , the multipole expansion @xmath161 is of the form @xmath203 $ ] . though one can not write , in arbitrary @xmath0 , a simple , closed - form expression for the object",
    "@xmath204 $ ] , it is enough to write down its expansion when @xmath205 ( which is in fact the same as its pn expansion ) .",
    "modulo regular terms near the origin , this expansion is obtained as @xmath206 & = & \\left(\\delta^{-1 } + \\frac{1}{c^2 } \\,\\partial_t^2\\delta^{-2 } + \\frac{1}{c^4 } \\,\\partial_t^4\\delta^{-3 } + \\cdots\\right ) \\bigl [ m_l(t ) \\delta(\\mathbf{x})\\bigr ] \\nonumber\\\\ & & + ~\\text{regular terms}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] using @xmath207 , @xmath208 _ etc .",
    "_ we see that the 3-dimensional form of the expansion of @xmath161 near @xmath171 ( after taking into account the expansion of the retardation @xmath168 ) , takes in @xmath0 dimensions the form @xmath209 where @xmath210 $ ] , @xmath211 is a ( relative ) integer , and @xmath212 . inserting this expansion in the second - order source @xmath213 yields @xmath214 at this stage , one could consider @xmath215 , without inserting a factor @xmath180 , by using the analytic continuation in @xmath0 .",
    "however , to ensure continuity with what was done in @xmath41 dimensions , it is better to insert this factor and to consider @xmath216.\\ ] ] the main difference between ( [ b6 ] ) and its 3-dimensional analogue ( [ b1 ] ) concerns the meromorphic structure of @xmath183 .",
    "indeed , in view of the shift by @xmath217 of the integer exponent @xmath211 in ( [ b5 ] ) , and of the presence of @xmath218 in the @xmath0-dimensional volume element @xmath219 , one easily sees that the ( simple ) _ poles _ in @xmath183 that were located at @xmath184 when @xmath28 are no longer located at @xmath184 when @xmath220 , but are _ shifted _ at @xmath221 .",
    "alternatively , this can be explicitly verified by using the expansion @xmath222 ( plus a regular kernel ) , and the formula @xmath223 $ ] where the pole at @xmath224 is the only one which comes from the ultraviolet ( uv ) behavior @xmath205 . as a consequence , the expansion ( [ b2 ] )",
    "is now modified to @xmath225 this expansion , and its analogues considered below , is considered for @xmath226 and @xmath179 both small ( so that the expansion in powers of @xmath179 makes sense ) , but without assuming any relative ordering between the smallness of @xmath179 and that of @xmath226 .",
    "one should neither re - expand @xmath227 in powers of @xmath228 nor in powers of @xmath229 .",
    "having in hand the above structure , one then _ defines _ the @xmath0-dimensional generalization of the finite part of @xmath163 as the coefficient of @xmath230 in eq .",
    "( [ b7 ] ) , namely @xmath231 .",
    "we denote such a finite part by    [ b8]@xmath232 & \\equiv & c_0^{(d)}(\\mathbf{x},t)\\,,\\\\ \\text{where}~~\\widetilde{r}&\\equiv&\\frac{r}{r_0}\\ , , \\label{rtilde}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    or , more simply , by @xmath233 note the subtlety that the expansion ( [ b7 ] ) is neither a laurent expansion in powers of @xmath234 , nor a laurent expansion in powers of @xmath179 . after subtracting",
    "the _ shifted _ pole terms @xmath235 , one expands the remainder in a regular taylor series in powers of @xmath179 .",
    "the interest of this specific definition is the fact that it ensures that @xmath236 is an exact solution of the equation we initially wanted to solve , namely @xmath237 indeed , by its mere definition ( [ b6 ] ) , one has @xmath238 . comparing this result ( which has no pole ) to the application of @xmath79 to ( [ b7 ] )",
    ", we first see that the pole part must be a homogeneous solution , @xmath239 .",
    "then , identifying the successive powers of @xmath179 ( using @xmath240 ) , yields @xmath241 , @xmath242 , and so on .",
    "another useful property of the @xmath0-modified definition ( [ b8 ] ) is that it automatically ensures the continuity between @xmath243 and @xmath28 .",
    "indeed , the shift in the location of the pole in ( [ b7 ] ) was made to `` follow '' the pole that existed at @xmath184 when @xmath28 .",
    "therefore we have @xmath244 , and similarly @xmath245 , _ etc .",
    "_ , where the rhss are those defined in eq .",
    "( [ b2 ] ) when @xmath28 .",
    "the extension of the iteration to higher non - linear orders introduces a new subtlety .",
    "indeed , let us look more precisely at the structure of the second - order contribution to the metric , @xmath246 where , as we said , the _ particular _ solution @xmath247 is defined by the modified fp process : @xmath248 , and where @xmath249 is a complementary homogeneous solution .",
    "most of the terms in the integrand @xmath250 introduce no poles , and , for them , we simply find a structure of the type @xmath251 ( for simplicity , we henceforth suppress angular factors ) .",
    "let us now consider the terms in @xmath250 that generate poles @xmath235 in @xmath183 .. however , similar terms appear at higher iteration orders , and their general structure is simpler to describe if we start our induction reasoning at the quadratically non - linear level . ] we know that such terms introduce , when @xmath28 , some logarithms of the radial variable @xmath126 .",
    "when @xmath252 , they no longer introduce logarithms but they introduce a further technical complication .",
    "indeed , let us look at a typical example , namely a dangerous term in @xmath183 of the form @xmath253 . suppressing for simplicity a factor @xmath254 which is jointly analytic in @xmath179 and @xmath226 near @xmath255 and @xmath256 respectively and therefore creates no problem , we have essentially @xmath257 . according to eq .",
    "( [ b7 ] ) the pole part of @xmath258 that we must subtract is , for instance , obtained by multiplying by @xmath234 and then taking the limit @xmath259 ( and _ not _",
    "@xmath185 ) .",
    "this pole part is therefore given by @xmath260 .",
    "the finite part of @xmath261 is then obtained by subtracting the pole part and taking the limit @xmath185 ; this yields @xmath262.\\ ] ] the subtlety is that there seems to appear poles in @xmath263 .",
    "however , the residue of the pole vanishes , since the limit @xmath264 of ( [ b10 ] ) is finite and generates the logarithm that we know to exist in @xmath28 , @xmath265 .",
    "if we do not take the limit @xmath264 , we must keep the structure ( [ b10 ] ) and see what it generates at the next , cubic , order of iteration .",
    "in addition , we must also add the complementary solution @xmath249 needed to satisfy the harmonicity condition , @xmath266 .",
    "as the calculation of @xmath249 could be done in @xmath28 without encountering poles ( see ref .",
    "@xcite ) , it will clearly not create problems in @xmath252 apart from the fact that @xmath249 , being a homogeneous solution @xmath267 , will behave near @xmath171 essentially like @xmath161 , _",
    "i.e. _ , @xmath268 ( which differs from most of the terms of @xmath247 which were @xmath269 ) .    summarizing so far , the second - order mpm iteration @xmath270 has a structure , near @xmath171 , of the symbolic form @xmath271,\\ ] ] where the @xmath272 s are analytic at @xmath256 , and where we explicitly separated the semi - singular structure in @xmath226 .",
    "when inserting the structure ( [ b11 ] ) into @xmath273 , one finds that the singular behavior of @xmath200 near @xmath171 can generate several types of singularities in @xmath179 and @xmath226 .",
    "there are simple poles @xmath235 and simple poles @xmath274 , which are natural generalizations of the structures that generated simple poles in @xmath183 .",
    "when looking at the effect of the more complicated structure given by the third term on the rhs of ( [ b11 ] ) , one finds that it is best described as generating some `` quasi - double poles '' , namely terms @xmath275 .",
    "the point is that if one were to expand this term in simple poles with respect to @xmath179 , namely @xmath276 it would seem to involve poles in @xmath277 .",
    "however , all such poles are `` spurious '' because the source of the trouble which is the last term in ( [ b11 ] ) had a finite limit as @xmath278 , and because one can easily see that , in our above - defined mpm algorithm , source terms having a finite limit as @xmath264 generate solutions having also a finite limit as @xmath264",
    ".    finally we find , by induction , that at each iteration order @xmath279 one has the structure @xmath280 where the coefficients @xmath281 might individually have ( simple or multiple ) poles in @xmath226 , _ e.g. _ @xmath282 , but which always compensate each other in the complete sum @xmath283 .",
    "then we obtain that the integral @xmath284\\ ] ] will have an expansion , near @xmath184 , of the generic form depend in fact on a set of integers @xmath285 .",
    "also we do not indicate the obvious dependence of the coefficients on the iteration order @xmath279 . ]",
    "@xmath286 the `` quasi - multiple poles '' which constitute the first term on the rhs have @xmath287 and @xmath288 . as we have seen in ( [ b11 ] ) and ( [ b11prime ] ) , the poles in @xmath277 are in fact spurious , as they have a residue which is always zero .",
    "[ we assume here that the seed multipole moments are regular as @xmath264 .",
    "] so , when writing the result in the form of ( [ b14 ] ) , we note that the coefficients @xmath289 , @xmath231 , _ etc .",
    "_ , are all regular when @xmath243 .",
    "one then defines the @xmath0-dimensional generalization of the finite part of @xmath290 as being the coefficient of @xmath230 in the expansion ( [ b14 ] ) : @xmath291 this coefficient is regular when @xmath292 , though it contains apparently singular terms of the type of the last term on the rhs of ( [ b11 ] ) .",
    "moreover , using the same reasoning as above , one finds that it satisfies the needed result : @xmath293 .",
    "note finally that , when @xmath294 , the quasi - multiple poles in ( [ b14 ] ) merge together to form the multiple poles @xmath295 , with @xmath287 , that were found to exist in @xmath28 @xcite . on the other hand , when @xmath296 , the poles form a `` line '' of _ simple _ poles located at @xmath297 , @xmath298 , @xmath134 , @xmath299 .",
    "however , it is better not to decompose the product of simple poles entering ( [ b14 ] ) in sum of separate simple poles , because this decomposition would , as in eq .",
    "( [ b12 ] ) , introduce spurious singularities @xmath300 .",
    "the main practical outcome of the present subsection is the modified definition of the operation @xmath301 when working in @xmath252 : namely as the coefficient of @xmath230 in an expansion of the type ( [ b14 ] ) where , after separating the shifted poles at @xmath234 , @xmath134 , @xmath302 , one expands the remainder in a taylor series in powers of @xmath179 .",
    "note that a simple consequence of this definition is that , for instance , a term of the form @xmath303 in @xmath304 $ ] gives rise to a finite part equal to 1 .",
    "@xmath305 = \\mathrm{fp}\\left [ \\frac{b - q\\varepsilon+q\\varepsilon}{b - q\\varepsilon}\\right ] = \\mathrm{fp}\\left [ \\frac{q\\varepsilon}{b - q\\varepsilon } + 1\\right ] = 1\\,.\\ ] ] one might have been afraid that a term of this type , @xmath303 , could have been ambiguous because , ultimately , we are sending both @xmath179 and @xmath226 towards zero without fixing an ordering between the two limits . however , in the present @xmath0-dimensional generalization of the mpm formalism , everything is precisely defined and unambiguous .",
    "we now sketch the @xmath0-dimensional generalization of the results concerning the matching between the mpm exterior metric and the inner field of a general post - newtonian ( pn ) matter system .",
    "to start with , we consider the case of a smooth matter distribution , and will later allow the matter stress - energy tensor to tend to a distribution localized on some world - lines .",
    "the next subsection will be devoted to the @xmath0-dimensional definition of the source multipole moments .",
    "the investigations of this and the next subsection are based on the works @xcite which derived the expressions of the source multipole moments of a general pn source , up to any pn order ( in @xmath41 dimensions ) .",
    "early derivations of the relativistic moments , valid up to 1pn order , can be found in refs .",
    "@xcite .",
    "we look for a solution , in the form of a pn expansion , of the @xmath0-dimensional einstein field equations .",
    "as before we choose some harmonic coordinates , which means that @xmath306 where the so - called `` gothic '' metric deviation reads @xmath307 , where @xmath308 is the determinant and @xmath309 the inverse of the usual covariant metric @xmath310 .",
    "then the einstein field equations , relaxed by the harmonic coordinate conditions , take the form of some `` scalar '' wave equations , similar to ( [ boxphi ] ) , for each of the components of @xmath138 , @xmath311 where @xmath79 denotes the @xmath0-dimensional flat space - time wave operator , and @xmath312 is the @xmath0-dimensional newton constant related to the usual newton constant @xmath313 in @xmath41 dimensions by eq .",
    "( [ gn ] ) below .",
    "the main contribution we shall add in the present subsection , with respect to our investigation of the scalar wave equation in sec .",
    "[ secii ] , is how to deal with the crucial _ non - linear _ gravitational source term in the einstein field equations , which makes the rhs of eq .",
    "( [ ee ] ) to have a support which is spatially _ non - compact_. the rhs of ( [ ee ] ) involves what can be called the total stress - energy pseudo tensor of the non - gravitational and gravitational fields , given by @xmath314 where @xmath315 is the matter stress - energy tensor , and the second term represents the gravitational stress - energy distribution , which can be expanded into non - linearities according to , we used @xmath316 , @xmath317 , and so on . ]",
    "@xmath318 where the quadratic , cubic , _ etc .",
    "_ , pieces admit symbolic structures such as @xmath319 and @xmath320",
    ".    the solution @xmath138 of the field equations we consider in this subsection will be smooth and valid everywhere , inside as well as outside the matter source localized in the domain @xmath87 .",
    "inside the source , or more generally inside the source s near zone ( @xmath321 , where @xmath11 is the wavelength of the emitted radiation ) , @xmath138 will admit a pn expansion , denoted here as @xmath322 . on the other hand , in the exterior of the source , @xmath170",
    ", @xmath138 will admit a multipolar expansion , solution of the vacuum field equations outside the source , and decomposed into ( @xmath0-dimensional ) irreducible spherical harmonics . as usual",
    ", the definition of the multipole expansion is extended by real analytic continuation in @xmath126 to any value @xmath173 .",
    "it will be necessary to introduce the special notation @xmath323 to mean the multipole expansion of @xmath138 .",
    "as we already mentioned , the multipole expansion in the present formalism is given by the mpm metric of sec .",
    "[ seciiia ] , which is therefore in the form of a formal infinite post-_minkowskian _ series up to any order @xmath279 , @xmath324 as mentioned above , though the identification ( [ multmpm ] ) is only physically meaningful in the exterior domain @xmath170 , it can be mathematically extended down to any @xmath173 by real analytic continuation in @xmath126 .    in this subsection",
    "we shall show how to relate in @xmath0 dimensions the multipolar expansion ( [ multmpm ] ) to the properties of the matter source , in the case of a pn source ( _ i.e. _ , one which is located deep inside its own near zone , @xmath325 ) .",
    "actually , the derivation below will be a simple @xmath0-dimensional adaptation of the proof given in the case of @xmath41 dimensions in ref .",
    "@xcite ( see notably the appendix a there ) .    the heart of the method is to show that one can deal with the presence of non - compact - support source terms on the rhs of the field equation ( [ ee ] ) , by considering a certain quantity @xmath326 which satisfies a wave equation whose source does have a compact support , and thus , whose multipolar expansion can be computed by using the results of sec .",
    "[ secii ] ( for each space - time component @xmath327 ) .",
    "this quantity is defined by @xmath328.\\ ] ] the second term in ( [ delta ] ) , that we thus _ subtract _ from @xmath138 in order to define this quantity , involves the finite part operation fp in @xmath0-dimensions which has been defined in the previous subsection ( [ seciiia ] ) .",
    "it contains the regularization factor @xmath329 .",
    "the use of the operator @xmath301 is consistent with sec .",
    "[ seciiia ] because it acts on the _ multipole expansion _ of the non - linear source term @xmath330 , which is in fact identical to the formal post - minkowskian ( mpm ) infinite series @xmath331 , _ cf .",
    "_ eq .  ( [ multmpm ] ) .",
    "the meaning of the last term on the rhs of ( [ delta ] ) is that @xmath301 is to be applied to each term of the mpm expansion of @xmath332 , and that we then consider the formal summation of this mpm series",
    ".    equation ( [ delta ] ) appears to be the difference . ] between the solution of the field equation ( [ ee ] ) and the contribution coming only from the non - linear terms in the exterior of the compact - support source ( and then analytically continued down to @xmath171 ) .",
    "since @xmath138 is the retarded integral of the pseudo tensor @xmath333 , and since the multipole expansion of the matter tensor is formally zero : @xmath334 ( because @xmath315 has a compact support ) , we can rewrite ( [ delta ] ) as @xmath335\\biggr\\}.\\ ] ] next , we remark that the first term in ( [ delta2 ] ) is regular within the source ( for @xmath87 ) , and that we can therefore add to it the same fp procedure as in the second term , without changing its value  because for regular sources , the operator @xmath336 simply gives back the usual retarded integral .",
    "thus , @xmath337.\\ ] ] as we said , the multipole moment formalism we are using is defined for general _ smooth _ matter distributions [ say @xmath338 with compact support .",
    "hence , @xmath333 is regular inside the source , and @xmath339 is a perfectly well - defined object . only when general formulas for the multipole moments are in hand , shall we apply them to point particles ( in sec .",
    "[ secv ] ) , and then shall we need a self - field regularization scheme to cure the divergencies induced by the point - particle model . of course the fp procedure used here should be carefully distinguished from the self - field regularization .",
    "the point is that @xmath326 , in the form given by eq .",
    "( [ delta3 ] ) , appears now as the retarded integral of a source with _ compact _ support ( limited to @xmath87 ) .",
    "this follows from the fact that @xmath333 agrees numerically with its own multipole expansion @xmath340 in the exterior of the source , for @xmath170 .",
    "hence we are allowed to use the end results of sec .",
    "[ secii ] which applied to compact - support sources ( and those results can evidently be `` uniformly '' applied to all the components of @xmath326 ) . from ( [ phimultg ] ) and ( [ shatl])([sellcompact ] ) we obtain @xmath341,\\ ] ] where the multipole - moment functions read @xmath342(\\mathbf{y},t+z\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert / c)\\,.\\ ] ] a difference with the multipole moments considered in sec .",
    "[ secii ] is the presence of the fp process with regularization factor @xmath343 .",
    "we shall see later the crucial role played by this fp process .",
    "now we deal with the integrand @xmath344 appearing in the multipole moments ( [ calf0initial ] ) , following the same argument as in ref .",
    "such an integrand has a compact support limited to @xmath87 , so we see that in the case of a pn source , for which @xmath325 , we can replace it with its formal pn expansion , because precisely the pn source is confined within the source s near zone .",
    "hence the pn - expanded moments will be generated by the pn - expanded integrand @xmath345 , where we denote the formal pn expansion with an overline .",
    "let us now show that the second term , @xmath346 , gives no contribution to the pn moments .",
    "we know that the structure of this term ( in @xmath347 dimensions ) reads @xmath348 where @xmath211 and @xmath349 are relative integers .",
    "this follows from eq .",
    "( [ b11prime ] ) above .",
    "the argument showing the vanishing of the term involving @xmath346 is that any term of the type ( [ struct ] ) in the moment will ultimately give [ after taking the pn expansion like in ( [ sellexpl ] ) ] a spatial integral of the type @xmath350 say ( times some function of time ) , which we know to be exactly _ zero _ by analytic continuation in @xmath179 .",
    "therefore , following this argument , which is in fact the same in @xmath0 dimensions as in @xmath41 dimensions , we are led _ in fine _ to a pn multipole moment which is simply generated by the _ pn expansion _ of the ( non - compact - support ) pseudo tensor , @xmath351 .",
    "hence , we write our result as @xmath352}^{\\mu\\nu}(\\mathbf{y},t)\\,,\\ ] ] where the @xmath94-dependent integrand takes the form of the following pn expansion , @xmath353}^{\\mu\\nu}(\\mathbf{y},t)&=&\\int_{-1}^1 dz \\,\\delta_\\ell^{(\\varepsilon ) } ( z ) \\,\\overline{\\tau}^{\\mu\\nu}(\\mathbf{y},t+z\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert / c ) \\nonumber\\\\ & = & \\sum_{k=0}^{+\\infty}\\alpha_\\ell^k \\left(\\frac{\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert}{c}\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}\\right)^{2k}\\overline{\\tau}^{\\mu\\nu}(\\mathbf{y},t)\\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the pn coefficients @xmath96 have been given in ( [ smult1b ] ) .",
    "note that the final result in ( [ calf1 ] ) combines two separate pn expansions : ( i ) a pn expansion of the type ( [ sell ] ) ( already indicated by an overline notation ) , and ( ii ) the usual pn expansion of @xmath333 .",
    "the presence of these pn expansions is crucial to the meaning and validity of the final expression in ( [ calf1 ] ) .",
    "finally , note that our use ( in the proof above ) of the vanishing of the spatial integrals @xmath350 implies that we have transformed the role of the factor @xmath354 from that of regularizing integrals that are singular at @xmath171 , into that of regularizing integrals that are singular at @xmath355 .",
    "thereby , in the final result ( [ calf1 ] ) , the fp procedure is used as a regularization of the boundary _ at infinity _ of the integral , which would otherwise be divergent because of the multipolar factor @xmath356 multiplying the non - compact - support ( and pn - expanded ) @xmath351 .      in eq .",
    "( [ mdelta ] ) we have represented the quantity @xmath326 , eq .",
    "( [ delta ] ) , in the form of an infinite superposition of _ scalar _ multipolar waves , say @xmath357 where we associate to any function of time @xmath358 a corresponding spherically symmetric retarded wave denoted dimensions we recover @xmath359 . recall that in any dimension the green function @xmath360 is in fact a function of @xmath361 and @xmath36 . ]",
    "@xmath362 in which the tensor indices @xmath327 play the role of simple `` spectators '' . this expansion is not yet a genuine _ irreducible tensorial _",
    "multipole expansion . to transform eq .",
    "( [ mdelta ] ) in a tensor multipole expansion , we need to decompose each `` elementary wave '' @xmath363 in _ irreducible _ representations of the @xmath0-dimensional rotation group @xmath63 . as each ( undifferentiated )",
    "elementary wave @xmath364 , eq .",
    "( [ fltilde ] ) , is spherically symmetric , the problem of decomposing @xmath364 in irreducible components is reduced to the purely algebraic problem of decomposing its `` source '' @xmath358 , whose expression is given by eqs .",
    "( [ calf0])([calf1 ] ) , in irreducible representations of @xmath63 .",
    "let us consider in turn the various components of @xmath358 .",
    "the time - time component @xmath365 is already put in irreducible form because it is stf with respect to the multi - index @xmath57 . in the language of young tableaux [ for @xmath63 ] , the stf-@xmath94 representation carried by @xmath365 is denoted by @xmath94 horizontal boxes .",
    "the time - space component @xmath367 is , algebraically , the product of an irreducible vector representation @xmath368 and of an irreducible stf-@xmath94 one @xmath369 . in young tableaux terms",
    ", this corresponds to the product . in any dimension",
    "@xmath0 , this product gives rise to three irreducible representations : the stf-@xmath370 one , the stf-@xmath371 one , and a _ mixed young tableau _ representation .",
    "the first two representations are easily understood as corresponding to the stf projection @xmath372 of the product @xmath373 , and the contraction @xmath374 .",
    "it is more intricate to write explicitly the mixed - young - tableau representation contained in @xmath375 . when @xmath28 , it was convenient to use the levi - civita antisymmetric tensor @xmath376 to dualize the two antisymmetric indices in the mixed young tableau ( _ i.e. _ , the two vertical boxes ) and replace them by a single vector index . however , when considering a generic value for the dimension @xmath0 ( initially taken as an integer , and then formally continued to arbitrary complex values ) , one is not allowed to use the specifically 3-dimensional tensor @xmath376 .",
    "when further considering the space - space component @xmath377 , one is facing the algebraic problem of decomposing the product .",
    "again the irreducible decomposition of this product contains both relatively simple _ symmetric _ representations , such as , and more involved _",
    "mixed_-young - tableau ones of the `` spin '' or `` weyl '' type . and @xmath377 in @xmath41",
    "dimensions , the levi - civita tensors always appear in pairs , and that the products @xmath378 which appear can always be entirely expressed in terms of kronecker deltas : @xmath379}$ ] . ]",
    "it is quite possible to write this decomposition in any ( integer ) dimension @xmath0 , by using mixed - young - tableau projectors instead of the @xmath376 duality operations used in @xmath28 .",
    "however , for the present work we can simplify our task and simply ignore all the mixed tableaux that appear in the irreducible decomposition of @xmath367 and @xmath377 .",
    "indeed , because of their irreducible character the symmetric young tableaux never mingle with the mixed - symmetry ones when doing linear operations , as is done when working with a linearized solution of einstein s equations .",
    "( this is easily checked when looking , for instance , at the derivation of the multipolar expansion of linearized gravity given in @xcite . )",
    "when considering the gauge - invariant content of @xmath138 ( _ i.e. _ , modulo a linearized gauge transformation ) , the symmetric representations will finally give rise to the so - called mass - type multipole moments , say @xmath159 , while the mixed one will correspond to what are called ( in @xmath28 ) the spin - type or current - type multipole moments , say @xmath380 .",
    "the aim of the present work is to cure the ambiguities , linked to logarithmic divergencies of integrals calculated in hadamard s regularization , which appeared at 3pn order in the calculations of refs .",
    "however , the works @xcite found that the only multipole moment which introduce ambiguities ( in @xmath28 ) at the 3pn order is the mass quadrupole moment @xmath381 . therefore , for our purpose , it is enough to derive general @xmath0-dependent formulas for the mass multipole moments @xmath159 ( besides the quadrupole @xmath381 we shall also need to consider below the mass dipole moment @xmath382 ) . we do not need to consider the definition of the current moments @xmath380 outside of @xmath28 . in view of what we said above , it is therefore enough to consider only the _ symmetric _ ( ) pieces in the irreducible decomposition of @xmath383 and @xmath377 . we then write    [ fdecomp]@xmath384 + \\delta_{ij}v_l\\nonumber\\\\ & + & \\text{``mixed tableaux''}\\ , , \\qquad\\label{fdecompc}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where the angular brackets surrounding indices refer to the stf projection , and where the tensors @xmath385 , @xmath386 , @xmath387 , @xmath388 , @xmath389 , @xmath390 , @xmath391 are all stf in their indices ( recall our notation for multi - indices : @xmath392 , @xmath393 , _ etc . _ ) .",
    "furthermore , we shall need below the inverse of eqs .",
    "( [ fdecomp ] ) , _ i.e. _ , the expressions of these tensors in terms of the @xmath394 s .",

    "( [ rel])([hatcalg0 ] ) is that the harmonicity conditions can be expressed by saying that the divergence of the multipole expansion @xmath397 reads    [ divmdeltashort]@xmath408    next we decompose the components of the function @xmath399 in stf guise , which means    [ gdecomp]@xmath409    where the tensors @xmath410 , @xmath411 and @xmath412 are all stf , together with the inverse formulas    [ gdecompinv]@xmath413    the relations ( [ divmdeltashort ] ) can then be re - stated as the following constraint equations linking the stf tensors ( to simplify , we set @xmath414 for a while ) ,    [ harmconstr ] @xmath415    our aim is now to obtain the linearized multipolar solution , which is at once solution of the source - free equations and divergenceless , and which will be exactly equal to the linearized metric @xmath416 of the mpm formalism . to this end , we introduce the object @xmath417 , given by the following multipole expansion in @xmath0 dimensions [ recall our notation ( [ fltilde ] ) ] ,    [ q1munu]@xmath418,\\\\ q^{i0}_1 & \\equiv & - 4\\,g \\left[-\\hbox{$\\int$}\\widetilde{q}^{(+)}_i + \\frac{3d+1}{2d}\\,\\dot{\\widetilde{q}}^{(-)}_i-\\sum_{\\ell\\geq 2}\\frac{(-)^\\ell}{\\ell ! } \\ ,",

    "@xmath419 , @xmath420 .",
    "the object @xmath421 , which is given here modulo the mixed tableaux corresponding notably to the spin - type contributions , exactly corresponds to the so - called `` harmonicity algorithm '' of ref .",
    "@xcite ( in the slightly modified version of it proposed in eqs .",
    "( 2.12 ) of @xcite ; notice that the latter equations are valid in any @xmath0 ) .",
    "the properties of @xmath417 are that @xmath422 _ and _ @xmath423= 0 $ ] , as one can easily verify by direct calculation . ) . in the present formalism",
    "the metric is past - stationary , and from this one can show that the functions involved which need to be time integrated are in fact zero in the past , before the instant @xmath186 , so that there is no problem in defining these anti - derivatives .",
    "] one now introduces the object @xmath424 as in @xcite one easily checks that @xmath425 defines a linearized multipolar metric ( in harmonic coordinates ) , which generates , by mpm iteration , the full metric @xmath323 .",
    "the source multipole moments are then defined as those which parametrize @xmath425 .",
    "the `` main '' multipole moments will be those which parametrize a specific piece of the linearized metric sometimes referred to as the `` canonical '' metric and which was introduced long ago in ref .",
    "the canonical metric , say @xmath426 , is separately divergenceless , and differs from @xmath425 by a linearized gauge transformation , with gauge vector say @xmath427 , @xmath428 it explicitly reads ( still consistently omitting the mixed tableaux )    [ h1can]@xmath429    where the tilde over the objects @xmath159 means , as in ( [ fltilde ] ) , @xmath430 such expressions clearly yield a precise definition of the mass - type stf multipole moments @xmath431 in @xmath0 dimensions ( and the mixed tableaux could be used to define some other , `` spin - type '' and `` weyl - type '' , moments ) .",
    "we need now to relate the moments @xmath159 entering ( [ h1can ] ) to the stf tensors which were used in the stf decomposition ( [ fdecomp ] ) of the function @xmath432 .    to this end",
    "it is most convenient to consider the gauge invariant _",
    "linearized curvature _ ( in @xmath0 dimensions ) associated with the metric deviation @xmath149 , in order to eliminate the irrelevant linearized gauge transformation in eq .",
    "( [ h1h1can ] ) .",
    "the component @xmath433 of the curvature , in terms of the gothic metric deviation , reads @xmath434&= & \\frac{1}{d-1}\\left[(d-2)\\partial_{i}\\partial_{j}h_1^{00 } + \\partial_{i}\\partial_{j}h_1^{kk } + \\delta_{ij}\\partial_{0}^2h_1^{00 } -\\delta_{ij}\\partial_{0}^2h_1^{kk}\\right]\\nonumber\\\\ & + & 2\\partial_{0 } \\partial_{(i}h_1^{j)0}+\\partial_{0}^2h_1^{ij}\\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] since @xmath149 and @xmath435 differ by a gauge transformation , eq .",
    "( [ h1h1can ] ) , we necessarily have @xmath436=0 $ ] , which immediately gives us ( looking at the particular term proportional to the double gradient @xmath437 ) the looked - for expression of the moment @xmath159 as being @xmath438 where the explicit powers of @xmath439 have now been restored .",
    "we find that @xmath159 is given in terms of the stf tensors parametrizing our original multipole - moment function @xmath432 and defined by eqs .",
    "( [ fdecomp ] ) , and also , in the last term of eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr0 ] ) , of the `` harmonicity '' function @xmath440 given by ( [ hatcalg0 ] ) .",
    "note that the last term of eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr0 ] ) involves a factor @xmath441 and therefore is absent in the 3-dimensional formalism of @xcite .",
    "since @xmath442 involves also a factor @xmath179 in its integrand , we see that the contribution induced in the moments by this term will be proportional to @xmath443 ; we shall see that such a contribution is actually zero .",
    "once we have obtained the moment @xmath431 , it is better to express it back in terms of the original function @xmath432 , since we know its relation to the pseudo tensor of the source , given by eqs .",
    "( [ calf0])([calf1 ] ) . using the inverse relations ( [ inverse ] ) and",
    "( [ gdecompinv ] ) , we get @xmath444\\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~ \\left.-\\frac{4(d+2\\ell-2)}{c^3(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell ) } \\dot{\\widehat{\\mathcal{f}}}_{il}^{i0 } \\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~\\left.+ \\frac{2(d+2\\ell-2)}{c^4(d+\\ell-1)(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell+2 ) } \\ddot{\\widehat{\\mathcal{f}}}_{ijl}^{\\langle ij\\rangle}\\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~\\left.- \\frac{4(d-3)(d+2\\ell-2)}{c^2(d-1)(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell ) } \\widehat{\\mathcal{g}}_{il}^i\\right\\}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] if we further introduce the following `` source - rooted '' quantities    [ sigma ] @xmath445    we can then write the moment into the following more explicit form @xmath446}(\\mathbf{y},t ) \\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~~\\left.-\\frac{4(d+2\\ell-2 ) } { c^2(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell)}\\,\\widehat{y}_{il}\\ , \\dot{\\overline{\\sigma}}_{i[\\ell+1]}(\\mathbf{y},t ) \\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~~\\left.+\\frac{2(d+2\\ell-2 ) } { c^4(d+\\ell-1)(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell+2 ) } \\,\\widehat{y}_{ijl}\\ , \\ddot{\\overline{\\sigma}}_{ij[\\ell+2]}(\\mathbf{y},t ) \\right.\\nonumber\\\\ & & \\qquad\\qquad~\\left.- \\frac{4(d-3)(d+2\\ell-2)}{c^2(d-1)(d+\\ell-2)(d+2\\ell ) } b \\,\\widehat{y}_{il}\\frac{y_j}{\\vert \\mathbf{y}\\vert^2 } \\overline{\\sigma}_{ij[\\ell+1]}(\\mathbf{y},t ) \\right\\},\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in which we denote the relevant infinite pn series of the source terms [ following our earlier notation ( [ calf1 ] ) ] by @xmath447}(\\mathbf{y},t)&=&\\int_{-1}^1 dz \\,\\delta_\\ell^{(\\varepsilon ) } ( z ) \\,\\overline\\sigma(\\mathbf{y},t+z\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert / c ) \\nonumber\\\\ & = & \\sum_{k=0}^{+\\infty}\\alpha_\\ell^k \\left(\\frac{\\vert\\mathbf{y}\\vert}{c}\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}\\right)^{2k}\\overline\\sigma(\\mathbf{y},t)\\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the numerical coefficients @xmath96 are given by eq .",
    "( [ smult1b ] ) , or more explicitly @xmath448 notice that with our conventions the newtonian limit , when @xmath449 , of the above defined relativistic moment @xmath159 takes the standard newtonian expression in any dimension @xmath0 , _",
    "i.e. _ , it does not contain any @xmath0-dependent factors in this limit : @xmath450 where the `` newtonian '' density of the fluid is @xmath451 .",
    "this is clear from the fact that the factor @xmath452 which appears in front of the expression of the multipole moment ( [ ilexpr2 ] ) , cancels out precisely the @xmath0-dependent factor in the newtonian approximation for @xmath453 , eq .",
    "( [ sigmaa ] ) , which is given by @xmath454 .",
    "finally , note that the last term in ( [ ilexpr1 ] ) or ( [ ilexpr2 ] ) is proportional to both @xmath179 and @xmath455 . to show that this term does not contribute to @xmath159",
    ", we can first decompose the integral over @xmath456 in two parts : ( i )  an integral @xmath457 over a compact domain @xmath458 containing the two particles , plus ( ii )  an integral @xmath459 over the outer domain @xmath460 .",
    "even if the integration near the particles introduces some uv poles @xmath16 , @xmath457 will be at worst proportional to @xmath461 , and will [ by the definition of the fp process , eq .",
    "( [ b15 ] ) ] give a vanishing finite part at @xmath184 .",
    "concerning @xmath459 , we shall prove in sec .",
    "[ secvb ] below that , even if it contains infrared ( ir)-type poles , its value is a _ continuous _ function of @xmath0 .",
    "now , because of the factor @xmath441 , the value in @xmath41 dimensions is zero , hence this term does not contribute to the moments and can be ignored in the present work ( this term was neglected in ref .",
    "in our 3pn calculations of the gravitational wave field , we will need the expressions of the sources @xmath453 , @xmath462 and @xmath463 , defined in eqs .",
    "( [ sigma ] ) above , up to orders @xmath464 , @xmath465 and @xmath466 respectively . the quickest method to obtain them consists in using the results of our previous work @xcite , in which the 3pn metric @xmath467 was expanded in terms of nine retarded potentials , introduced in @xcite when @xmath28 and generalized to @xmath0 dimensions in @xcite .",
    "starting from the matter source densities @xmath468 we first defined the `` linear '' potentials @xmath469 these linear potentials were then used to construct higher `` non - linear '' potentials , such as @xmath470,\\ ] ] and six other ones ( denoted @xmath471 , @xmath472 , @xmath473 , @xmath474 , @xmath475 , @xmath476 ) whose field equations are explicitly given in eqs .  ( 2.12 ) of ref .",
    "we computed all of them for a binary system of point masses , in spatial dimension @xmath347 close to 3 , at any field point in the case of linear potentials such as ( [ potlin ] ) , and , for the more difficult non - linear ones like ( [ wij ] ) , in the vicinity of the particles as laurent - type expansions in powers of the radial distances to them . the retardations in these potentials were also systematically expanded to the required pn order .    for our present calculation of the 3pn gravitational wave field ,",
    "only the expressions of the first seven potentials ( @xmath477 , @xmath478 , @xmath471 , @xmath479 , @xmath472 , @xmath473 , @xmath480 ) will actually be necessary . from eqs .",
    "( [ ee ] ) and ( [ sigma ] ) above , the sources @xmath453 , @xmath462 and @xmath463 may be expressed in terms of the `` gothic '' metric @xmath481 as    [ sigh ] @xmath482    where @xmath312 denotes by definition the gravitational constant entering the @xmath483-dimensional einstein equations ( [ ee ] ) . as underlined in ref .",
    "@xcite , it is related to the usual newton constant ( in 3 spatial dimensions ) @xmath313 by @xmath484 where @xmath485 is an arbitrary length scale , which will enter our dimensionally regularized calculation below but will drop out of the final physical observables .    to identify the sources ( [ sigh ] ) , it thus suffices to write einstein s equations @xmath486 $ ] in harmonic gauge and in terms of the gothic metric @xmath487 .",
    "a possible method would be to use the expression of the ricci tensor in terms of @xmath487 that we gave in eq .",
    "( a9 ) of ref .",
    "@xcite , for any dimension @xmath0 .",
    "it is however quicker to use directly the full 3pn form of @xmath467 that we obtained in this reference , which can be translated in terms of @xmath487 thanks to eqs .",
    "( a3 ) and ( a8 ) of @xcite .",
    "the result not only depends on the nine introduced potentials ( @xmath477 , @xmath478 , @xmath471 , @xmath479 , @xmath472 , @xmath473 , @xmath480 , @xmath475 , @xmath476 ) , but the @xmath488 order in @xmath489 actually depends also on the 4pn ( @xmath488 ) contribution to the spatial metric @xmath490 , that was not computed in @xcite . however , the combination entering eq .",
    "( [ sigh1 ] ) above precisely cancels this uncomputed contribution , and one gets straightforwardly    [ gothmet ] @xmath491 \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{1}{c^6}\\biggl [ 8\\hat x + 4 v\\hat w + \\frac{4}{3}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)^2 v^3 \\nonumber\\\\ & & - 8 \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-1}\\right ) v_iv_i - \\frac{8(d-1)(d-3)}{(d-2)^2 } k v \\biggr ] \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{1}{c^8}\\biggl [ 32\\hat t + 16\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v\\hat x + 16 v \\hat z + 4\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v^2\\hat w \\nonumber\\\\ & & - \\frac{8}{d-1 } \\hat w_{ij}\\hat w_{ij } + \\frac{4}{d-1 }",
