    "w\\right ) -\\frac{16}{c^6}\\left(\\hat z_{ij } -\\frac{1}{2}\\delta_{ij}\\hat z\\right ) + \\mathcal{o}\\left(\\frac{1}{c^8}\\right ) , \\label{gothmetc}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where @xmath492 and @xmath493 denote the traces of the corresponding potentials . equations ( 2.12 ) of ref .",
    "@xcite then allow us to compute the dalembertian of these metric coefficients in terms of the first seven potentials , and one gets the following explicit form for the sources :    [ sources ] @xmath494 \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{\\pi g c^6}\\biggl [ \\frac{16 \\pi g}{d-2 } \\sigma v_i v_i + 4\\pi g \\frac{5-d}{(d-2)^2 } \\sigma_{ii } v^2 + \\frac{8 \\pi g}{d-1 } \\sigma_{ij}\\hat w_{ij } - 8\\pi g\\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right ) \\sigma \\hat x \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{4}{3}\\pi g\\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right)^3\\sigma v^3 -8\\pi g\\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right)^3 \\sigma v k + 8\\pi g \\frac{(5-d)(d-3)}{(d-1)(d-2)}\\sigma_i v_i v \\nonumber\\\\ & & + 16\\pi g\\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-1}\\right)\\sigma_i\\hat r_i - 8\\pi g \\frac{d-3}{(d-2)^2}\\sigma_{ii}k \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{2}\\hat w\\partial_t^2 v + \\frac{1}{2 } v\\partial_t^2\\hat w -\\frac{1}{2}\\frac{(4-d)(d-1)^2}{(d-2)^3 } v\\left(\\partial_t v\\right)^2 -\\frac{d(d-1)}{(d-2)^2 } v_i \\partial_t v\\partial_i v \\nonumber\\\\ & & -2\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v v_i \\partial_t \\partial_i v - 4\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v_i \\partial_j v_i \\partial_j v + \\frac{4}{d-1}\\left(\\partial_t v_i\\right)^2 + \\partial_t v\\partial_t\\hat w \\nonumber\\\\ & & + 4 \\partial_i v_j \\partial_t \\hat w_{ij } -4 \\hat z_{ij } \\partial_{ij } v - 4 \\hat r_i \\partial_t\\partial_i v + 8 \\partial_i v_j \\partial_j \\hat r_i - 2\\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-1}\\right ) v_i \\partial_t^2 v_i \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{(4-d)(d-1)(d-3)}{(d-2)^3 } \\partial_t v \\partial_t k + 4 \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right ) v_i \\partial_t\\partial_i k + 2 \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right ) \\hat w_{ij } \\partial_{ij } k \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{1}{12 } \\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)^3 \\delta\\left(v^4\\right )",
    "-\\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(v^2\\hat w\\right ) - \\frac{1}{2(d-1)}\\delta\\left(\\hat",
    "w^2\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{d-1}\\delta\\left(\\hat w_{ij}\\hat w_{ij}\\right ) - 2 \\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(v\\hat x\\right ) - 2\\delta\\left(v\\hat z\\right ) - \\frac{(d-1)(d-3)^2}{(d-2)^3 } \\delta\\left(k^2\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & + 4 \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-1}\\right ) \\delta\\left(\\hat r_i v_i\\right ) + \\frac{(d-1)^2(d-3)}{(d-2)^3}\\delta\\left(k v^2\\right ) + \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(k\\hat w\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & + 2 \\left(\\frac{d-3}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(v v_i v_i\\right)\\biggr ] + \\mathcal{o}\\left(\\frac{1}{c^8}\\right ) , \\label{sourcesa}\\\\ \\sigma_i & = & \\sigma_i + \\frac{1}{\\pi g c^2}\\biggl [ \\frac{5-d}{d-2 } \\pi g \\sigma_i v - \\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\pi g \\sigma v_i \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)\\partial_k v\\partial_i v_k + \\frac{d(d-1)}{8(d-2)^2}\\partial_t v\\partial_i v -\\frac{1}{4}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(v v_i\\right)\\biggr]\\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{\\pi g c^4}\\biggl [ \\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{5-d}{d-2}\\right)^2 \\pi g \\sigma_i v^2 - 2\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)\\pi g \\sigma \\hat r_i + \\frac{2\\pi g}{d-2}\\sigma_{kk } v_i \\nonumber\\\\ & & + 2 \\pi g \\sigma_k \\hat w_{ik } + 2\\pi g \\sigma_{ik } v_k + 2\\frac{(d-1)(d-3)}{(d-2)^2}\\pi g \\sigma v",
    "v_i -2 \\frac{(5-d)(d-3)}{(d-2)^2}\\pi g \\sigma_i k \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{4}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v_i \\partial_t^2 v - \\frac{1}{4}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) v \\partial_t^2 v_i + \\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\partial_t v \\partial_t v_i -2 v_k \\partial_k\\partial_t v_i \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{8}\\frac{d(d-1)^2}{(d-2)^3}v\\partial_t v\\partial_i v -\\frac{1}{4}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)^2 v_i \\partial_k v \\partial_k v + \\frac{1}{4 } \\frac{d(d-1)}{(d-2)^2 } v_k \\partial_i v \\partial_k v \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\partial_k v",
    "\\partial_i \\hat r_k -\\hat w_{kl}\\partial_{kl } v_i + \\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\partial_t\\hat w_{ik}\\partial_k v -\\partial_i \\hat w_{kl}\\partial_k v_l + \\partial_k \\hat w_{il}\\partial_l v_k",
    "\\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{(d-1)(d-3)}{(d-2)^2 } \\partial_k k \\partial_i v_k -\\frac{d(d-1)(d-3)}{4(d-2)^3 } \\left(\\partial_t v \\partial_i k + \\partial_i",
    "v \\partial_t k\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{1}{8}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right)^2 \\delta\\left(v^2 v_i\\right ) -\\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\delta\\left(v \\hat r_i\\right ) -\\frac{1}{2 } \\delta\\left(\\hat w v_i\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{2 } \\delta\\left(\\hat w_{ij } v_j\\right ) + \\frac{1}{2 } \\frac{(d-1)(d-3)}{(d-2)^2 } \\delta\\left(v_i k\\right)\\biggr ] + \\mathcal{o}\\left(\\frac{1}{c^6}\\right ) , \\label{sourcesb}\\\\ \\sigma_{ij } & = & \\sigma_{ij } + \\frac{1}{8\\pi g}\\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\left(\\partial_i v\\partial_j v -\\frac{1}{2}\\delta_{ij } \\partial_k v \\partial_k v\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & + \\frac{1}{\\pi g c^2 } \\biggl\\ { \\frac{4\\pi g}{d-2}\\sigma_{ij } v + \\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\partial_t v_{(i}\\partial_{j ) }",
    "v -\\partial_i v_k \\partial_j v_k -\\partial_k v_i \\partial_k v_j + 2 \\partial_k v_{(i}\\partial_{j)}v_k \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{(d-1)(d-3)}{2(d-2)^2 } \\partial_{(i } v \\partial_{j ) } k + \\delta_{ij } \\biggl [ \\frac{1}{2 } \\partial_k v_m \\partial_k v_m -\\frac{1}{2 } \\partial_k v_m \\partial_m v_k -\\frac{d(d-1)}{16(d-2)^2}\\left(\\partial_t v\\right)^2 \\nonumber\\\\ & & -\\frac{1}{2 } \\left(\\frac{d-1}{d-2}\\right ) \\partial_t v_k \\partial_k v + \\frac{(d-1)(d-3)}{4(d-2)^2}\\partial_k v \\partial_k k \\biggr ] \\biggr\\ } + \\mathcal{o}\\left(\\frac{1}{c^4}\\right ) . \\label{sourcesc}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    note that although we did use the full 3pn expression of the metric in the intermediate steps of this calculation , the sources @xmath453 , @xmath462 and @xmath463 actually depend only on the 2pn metric and on the potential @xmath495 ( entering the trace of the 3pn spatial metric @xmath490 ) .",
    "the mass - type moment @xmath159 can now be obtained by inserting the above expressions into eqs .",
    "( [ ilexpr2])([series ] ) , thereby generalizing to @xmath0 dimensions the 3-dimensional results ( 3.4)(3.6 ) of ref .",
    "@xcite .    the above method to derive eqs .",
    "( [ sources ] ) not only avoids redoing some of the calculations of ref .",
    "@xcite , but it also yields the results in a useful form .",
    "indeed , the laplacians of product of potentials , say @xmath496 , are easier to compute than their expanded form @xmath497 ( where @xmath498 and @xmath499 may be replaced by their corresponding sources ) . in particular , when computing the contributions of such laplacians to the moment @xmath159 , eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) , their lowest - order terms ( @xmath500 ) in eq .",
    "( [ series ] ) do not contribute to the difference between the dimensional and pure - hadamard - schwartz ( phs ) regularizations ; see eq .",
    "( 4.23 ) of ref .",
    "@xcite and sec .",
    "[ secvb ] below .",
    "however , the retardation corrections ( @xmath501 ) entering eq .",
    "( [ series ] ) do contribute to this difference .    to ease the reading , we classified the various terms of eqs .",
    "( [ sources ] ) in different sets , at each successive pn order : first the compact - support terms ( proportional to @xmath502 , @xmath503 or @xmath504 ) , which do not contribute to the difference between the dimensional and phs regularizations below ; second the main non - compact contributions , which are crucial for this difference ; and finally the non - compact terms proportional to the laplacian of a product of potentials , which do not contribute to the difference at lowest order . in each set of terms",
    ", we also gathered at the end those which are proportional to @xmath441 .",
    "these terms are absent in @xmath28 , and notably all those which involve the potential @xmath471 .",
    "note finally that in expression ( [ sourcesc ] ) , none of the terms proportional to @xmath70 contributes to our present calculation , since @xmath463 is multiplied by the trace - free tensor @xmath505 in eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) .",
    "we nevertheless quote these terms for completeness , as they may be useful for future works .",
    "let us first recall that the general strategy we are following , in order to obtain the complete 3pn wave generation from two point masses , consists of two main steps .",
    "they have been devised at the occasion of the application of dimensional regularization ( dr ) to the problem of the 3pn equations of motion @xcite , and are :    1 .   to obtain the expression of the 3pn mass quadrupole moment in the case of two point masses , using for the required self - field regularization the so - called _ pure - hadamard - schwartz _ ( phs ) regularization ; 2 .   to add to the phs",
    "result the _ difference _ between dr and the phs regularization , which , as we shall see , is exclusively due to the presence of poles in @xmath0 dimensions ( proportional to @xmath277 ) .",
    "step  ( i ) has already been achieved in our previous papers devoted to hadamard - regularization computations of the multipole moments @xcite ; the present paper deals with step  ( ii ) of this general method , and constitutes the central part of our application of dimensional regularization in the problem .",
    "we refer to @xcite for a precise definition of the phs regularization , and to @xcite for a summary and discussion of the overall method .",
    "note that , in order to apply step ( ii ) we transformed a few terms in the expression obtained by inserting the effective sources ( [ sources ] ) into the multipole moments @xmath159 so as to exactly parallel the form used in @xcite .",
    "this is notably the case for terms that will be discussed in sec .",
    "[ secvii ] below .    a well known result ( see refs .",
    "@xcite ) is that at the 3pn order , hadamard s regularization , and in fact any of its variants like the phs one , permits the computation of most of the terms ( both in the equations of motion and in the radiation field at infinity ) , _ except for a few _ terms which are `` ambiguous '' in the sense that this particular regularization gives different results for certain divergent integrals , depending on how one performs the integration ( _ e.g. _ , by integrating by parts or not ) .",
    "in fact , the ambiguous integrals are those which exhibit some _ logarithmic _ divergencies , corresponding to the occurrence of poles in @xmath0 dimensions . as it turns out , the structure of the ambiguous terms is always of a simple and limited type , and can therefore be parametrized by means of a few arbitrary unknown numerical constants called the `` _ _ ambiguity parameters _ _ '' .",
    "it was shown in refs .",
    "@xcite that the hadamard regularization of the 3pn mass - quadrupole moment @xmath381 of point particle binaries is complete up to _ three _ and only three ambiguity parameters , which were denoted by @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 .",
    "the regularization used in the first work @xcite was a certain variant of the hadamard regularization called `` hybrid '' , and the ambiguity parameters @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 were originally defined with respect to that hybrid regularization .",
    "the next calculation , performed in @xcite , has been based on the phs regularization [ step  ( i ) ] , and therefore we had to perform some numerical shifts of the values of @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 , in order to take into account the different reference points for their definition ( hybrid regularization in @xcite , phs one in @xcite ) .",
    "an important and non trivial check of these computations has precisely been the very _ existence of a unique numerical shift _ for each of the ambiguity parameters , such that the results of both the computations @xcite and @xcite are in complete agreement . indeed , as we said , these two computations differ in the adopted regularizations , but they also differ by many details concerning their technical implementations , like the use of different `` elementary '' potentials . indeed , in @xcite some instantaneous poisson - like versions of the elementary potentials , say @xmath506 , @xmath507 , @xmath134 , were adopted .",
    "however , in ref .",
    "@xcite we preferred to use the retarded elementary potentials @xmath477 , @xmath478 , @xmath134 , which are the same as in the work on the equations of motion @xcite , and also the same as those we employ in the present paper ( see sec .",
    "[ seciv ] ) .      in this section",
    "we derive a general formula for the `` difference '' between dr and the pure - hadamard - schwartz ( phs ) regularization .",
    "we shall not review the meaning and precise definition of the phs regularization , and simply refer to sec .",
    "iii of @xcite and sec .",
    "iv of @xcite for full details .",
    "the difference investigated here concerns the typical ( non - compact - support ) terms occurring in the multipole moments , which are in the form of some spatial integrals over @xmath508 or @xmath509 .",
    "our investigation parallels the one of sec .",
    "ivb in @xcite , which dealt with the difference for the case of poisson and poisson - like potentials , appropriate to the equations of motion .",
    "however , because the poisson potentials depend not only on time @xmath36 but also on the field point @xmath510 , while the integrals we consider here for the multipole moments are functions of time @xmath36 only , the derivation of the end formula will be substantially simpler than in the case of the equations of motion , so we shall only give the main result .    in @xmath41 dimensions the generic functions we have to deal with , say @xmath511 , are smooth on @xmath508 except at two singular points @xmath512 and @xmath513 , around which they admit laurent - type expansions in powers ( and inverse powers ) of @xmath514 and @xmath515 .",
    "depends also on time @xmath36 , through for instance their dependence on the velocities @xmath516 and @xmath517 , but the ( coordinate ) @xmath36 time is purely `` spectator '' in the regularization process , and thus will not be indicated . ]",
    "when @xmath518 we have ( for any @xmath519 ) @xmath520 the landau symbol @xmath521 takes its usual meaning ; the coefficients @xmath522 depend on the unit vector @xmath523 .",
    "since the powers @xmath211 can be positive as well as negative integers , the expansion ( [ fx ] ) is singular , but there is a maximal order of divergency , @xmath524 .    in @xmath0 dimensions , there is an analogue of the function @xmath525 , which results from the same detailed pn iteration process as the one leading to @xmath525 but performed in @xmath0 dimensions ( see the discussion in @xcite ) ; let us call this @xmath0-dimensional function @xmath526 , where @xmath527 .",
    "when @xmath518 this function admits a singular expansion which is more complicated than in @xmath41 dimensions , and reads @xmath528 with dimension - dependent coefficients @xmath529 ( recall that @xmath108 ) , and where @xmath211 and @xmath349 are relative integers whose values are limited by some @xmath530 , @xmath531 and @xmath532 as indicated .",
    "we will be interested here in integrands @xmath526 which have no poles as @xmath278 ( the poles in @xmath159 being generated by integrating these integrands ) , since this will always be the case at 3pn order .",
    "therefore , we deduce from the fact that @xmath526 is continuous at @xmath28 , _",
    "i.e. _ , @xmath533 , the constraint @xmath534    in the present paper we are interested in spatial integrals @xmath535 representing generic terms in the multipole moments . here , @xmath526 is a _ non - compact - support _ term in the integrand of the multipole moments , which follows from eqs .",
    "( [ sources ] ) in sec .",
    "[ seciv ] above .",
    "we do not consider the compact support terms ( proportional to @xmath502 , @xmath503 and @xmath504 ) since their contribution to the moments has already been computed in ref .",
    "@xcite and they give no contribution in the `` difference '' between the dimensional and phs regularizations .",
    "furthermore , we assume in the definition of the function @xmath536 that the derivatives of the elementary potentials therein are taken in the ordinary , non distributional sense ( we further comment below on how the distributional parts of the derivatives have been taken into account into the formalism ) . furthermore we do not need to consider here the non - compact - support terms in the multipole moments which have a form such that their spatial integral depends solely on the boundary at infinity , @xmath537 .",
    "these terms have been discussed in sec .",
    "ivd of @xcite ; they provide a crucial contribution to the multipole moments in @xmath41 dimensions computed in @xcite .",
    "however , we shall show in sec .",
    "[ secvb ] below that , thanks to the @xmath0-dimensional generalization of the finite part process @xmath538 defined in sec .",
    "[ seciiia ] above , these terms do not contribute to the difference `` dr - hr '' we are interested in .    finally , we take for @xmath536 a generic non - compact - support term , whose integral can not be expressed as an integral at infinity , _",
    "i.e. _ , not of the form which is discussed in sec .",
    "ivd of @xcite .",
    "the general structure of such @xmath536 is that of a multipolar factor @xmath539 times some multilinear functional , say @xmath540 , of the elementary potentials ( in @xmath0 dimensions ) and their derivatives , @xmath541\\,.\\ ] ] for the present calculation , the derivatives of potentials in this definition , @xmath542 , are ordinary derivatives .",
    "many terms of eqs .",
    "( [ sources ] ) are made of a spatial integral applied to some partial time derivative of a function of the type @xmath536 .",
    "for these terms we always put the time derivatives outside the integral and perform first the spatial integral using the regularization , and only then apply the ( total ) time derivative .    since we shall prove in sec .",
    "[ secvb ] that the difference between the integrals involving @xmath536 and @xmath543 does not involve any contribution coming from divergencies `` at infinity '' , we limit ourselves to spatial integrals which extend over a finite volume in the @xmath0-dimensional space , say the spherical ball @xmath544 defined by @xmath545 , where @xmath546 denotes some arbitrary constant radius .",
    "the results we shall derive below will not depend on @xmath546 . in hadamard",
    "s regularization , and particularly in the phs variant of it , the @xmath41-dimensional spatial integral is defined by the so - called _ partie finie _",
    "( pf ) prescription , depending on two arbitrary constants @xmath547 and @xmath548 , say @xmath549 of course @xmath550 is in fact a function of time but we do not need to indicate this . by definition ,",
    "hadamard s partie finie integral is given by the following limit when the radius @xmath551 of two `` regularizing volumes '' surrounding the singularities tends to zero , say @xmath552 the symbol @xmath553 means the same terms but with the singularities labels 1 and 2 exchanged .",
    "the first term represents an ordinary integral extending over the region obtained from @xmath544 by excising two spherical balls @xmath554 and @xmath555 centered on the two singularities , each having the same radius @xmath551 ( evidently we can always assume @xmath556 ) .",
    "the extra terms in ( [ pf ] ) , which are such that they cancel out the singular part of the first term when @xmath557 ( so that the partie finie exists by definition ) , involve the usual ( two - dimensional ) spherical average @xmath558 where @xmath559 is the solid angle element around @xmath560 .",
    "the length scales @xmath547 and @xmath548 ( one for each particle ) are introduced in eq .",
    "( [ pf ] ) in order to adimensionalize the radius @xmath551 in the logarithmic terms .",
    "they play a key role at 3pn order , since their appearance signals the presence of logarithmic divergences which correspond to poles @xmath561 in @xmath0 dimensions .",
    "a way to interpret these constants is to say that they reflect an arbitrariness in the original choice of the two regularizing volumes @xmath554 and @xmath555 .    in dimensional",
    "regularization the situation is much simpler , since the integral will be ( so to speak ) `` automatically '' regularized by means of the analytic continuation of the @xmath0-dimensional volume element .",
    "thus , we simply have @xmath562 where @xmath563 is the @xmath0-dimensional ball with radius @xmath546 .",
    "given the results of the two regularizations , ( [ h ] ) and ( [ hd ] ) , we consider what we call the difference , which is what we shall have to add to the phs result in order to obtain the dr result , namely @xmath564 we shall compute @xmath565 in the limit where @xmath2 , keeping the pole part @xmath566 ( at 3pn order only simple poles will occur ) and the finite term @xmath567 , but neglecting @xmath568 . using the same method as in @xcite ,",
    "@xmath565 can be obtained by splitting the @xmath0-dimensional integral ( [ hd ] ) into three volumes , two spherical balls @xmath569 and @xmath570 of radius @xmath551 , which are the @xmath0-dimensional analogues of @xmath554 and @xmath555 , and the complementary volume in @xmath563 , say @xmath571 . it is clear that the integral over the latter complementary volume reduces , when @xmath2 ( with fixed @xmath551 ) , to the integral over @xmath572 , which is the first term in the definition ( [ pf ] ) of hadamard s partie finie , and does not contribute to the difference modulo some negligible terms @xmath568 .",
    "it remains thus the `` local '' contributions of the two volumes @xmath569 and @xmath570 , which can be straightforwardly computed from inserting into them the local singular expansions given by ( [ fdx ] ) and @xmath553 .",
    "we can then connect the result to the corresponding result in @xmath41 dimensions by using the constraint ( [ constr ] ) .",
    "finally , we obtain for the difference @xmath565 the following outcome : @xmath573 \\bigl<\\mathop{f}_1{}_{-3,q}^{(\\varepsilon)}\\bigr>_{2+\\varepsilon } + 1\\leftrightarrow 2 + \\mathcal{o}(\\varepsilon)\\,,\\ ] ] where the spherical average _ performed in @xmath0 dimensions _ is defined by @xmath574 the volume of the @xmath575-dimensional sphere , embedded into @xmath0-dimensional space , is given by @xmath576 ; for instance , @xmath577 .",
    "actually , we can see that the @xmath578 s cancel out between ( [ dhres ] ) and ( [ averaged ] ) .",
    "let us now comment on the inclusion in the present formalism of derivatives in a _",
    "distributional _ sense .",
    "an important feature of the phs regularization is the systematic use of distributional derivatives _  la _",
    "schwartz @xcite .",
    "it has been shown both in the contexts of the equations of motion @xcite and of the radiation field @xcite that the purely distributional parts of derivatives yield a crucial physical contribution to the results at the 3pn order . in hadamard",
    "s regularization , various prescriptions are possible for the distributional derivatives .",
    "for instance , some generalized distributional derivatives , defined in the extended hadamard regularization @xcite , were used for the 3pn equations of motion in @xcite . using different prescriptions",
    "yields different results , which however differ at the 3pn order by some terms having the form of the ambiguous terms , and therefore which merely change the values of the ambiguity parameters ( @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 in the radiation field ) .",
    "now we showed @xcite that in dr the correct prescription for the derivatives is the one of the standard distribution theory @xcite .",
    "this is why we have included schwartz derivatives in the definition of the phs regularization , which constitutes in some sense the `` core '' part of dr , by which we mean the part which computes all the difficult non - linear integrals , but leaves unspecified a few terms corresponding exclusively to the `` ambiguous '' logarithmic divergences . of course , since different variants of hadamard s regularization differ precisely in different definitions for the ambiguity parameters , all of them could be regarded as the `` core '' of dr . however , the point is that the phs regularization is the only one for which the final result of dr is to be obtained by adding exactly the `` difference '' in the way we have computed it in eq .",
    "( [ dhres ] ) . to summarize , eq .",
    "( [ dhres ] ) as its stands is simply to be added to the phs result , since the latter already includes the distributional derivatives _  la _ schwartz , whose contributions have been computed in ref .",
    "@xcite .",
    "let us recall the logic that led us to introducing and using the specific , @xmath0-dimensionally generalized , finite part ( fp ) process .",
    "initially , in the mpm construction of the multipole expansion of the external metric , when iteratively solving einstein s equations , we were faced with some integrands @xmath579 that had a singular behavior at the origin of the spatial coordinates , _",
    "i.e. _ , as @xmath205 .",
    "one then _ defined _ the fp of the retarded integral of @xmath579 by first introducing a factor @xmath580 in the integrand , and then subtracting the `` quasi - multiple '' shifted poles @xmath581 [ first term on the rhs of eq .",
    "( [ b14 ] ) ] , before taking the continuation down to @xmath184 . at this stage ,",
    "the integrand was , in principle , defined as a post - minkowskian expansion , with good convergence properties at @xmath582 , so that the poles @xmath583 came only from the region where @xmath584 .",
    "later , the external mpm construction was combined with a straightforward post - newtonian ( pn ) iteration of einstein s equations , which took into account the interior region containing the material source @xmath315 . with a generalization of the argument used in @xcite",
    ", one could formally relate the source multipole moments , used in the mpm formalism to parametrize the source , to integrals over the pn expansion of the effective stress - energy pseudo tensor @xmath585 non - linear terms .",
    "this led to what was the starting point of our investigation , namely to formal expressions for the source multipole moments ( of the mass type ) of the symbolic form @xmath586 where we recall that the overline denotes a pn ( or near zone ) expansion .",
    "note that the presence of this pn expansion process in eq .",
    "( [ 4.1 ] ) is crucial to its validity .",
    "indeed , the argument used to derive ( [ 4.1 ] ) was based on transforming mpm - expanded integrands singular when @xmath587 into pn - expanded ones diverging when @xmath582 .",
    "( as discussed in @xcite the formal limit @xmath582 , taken within a pn - expanded integrand , physically corresponds to the `` outer near zone '' @xmath588 , and should not be confused with a far zone expansion @xmath589 , in the sense of spatial infinity @xmath590 . ) technically , the transformation between the two types of singular integrals was based on the analytic continuation with respect to @xmath179 of the integrals , using the fact that @xmath591 . in this reshuffling from the uv ( @xmath587 ) to the ir ( @xmath592 )",
    "it was essential to keep the same meaning of the symbol fp in front of ( [ 4.1 ] ) .",
    "indeed , one sees easily , by separating @xmath593 into @xmath594 and @xmath595 that the mpm - poles @xmath596 generated near @xmath171 ( when @xmath597 ) become transformed in the same ( modulo a sign ) poles , generated near @xmath598 by the singular behavior of the pn integrand .",
    "in addition to the poles @xmath583 present in the integral ( [ 4.1 ] ) , and generated by the behavior of the pn - expanded non - linear terms @xmath599 at @xmath582 , there are also poles @xmath600 associated to the singular behavior of @xmath601 near @xmath602 and @xmath603 . but clearly , if we split the integral @xmath604 in a part @xmath605 enclosing the two mass points , and a complementary part @xmath606 , the latter integral will have no singularities associated to @xmath607 or @xmath608 , and therefore will have no genuine poles @xmath263 .",
    "the conclusion is that the restriction of the integral ( [ 4.1 ] ) to the outer near zone @xmath606 ( corresponding to the ir ) , say @xmath609 is a meromorphic function of the complex variables @xmath179 and @xmath226 which will have , when @xmath179 and @xmath226 are both near zero , the same type of quasi - multiple shifted poles structure as the mpm quantity @xmath610 of eq .",
    "( [ b14 ] ) , say @xmath611 the important point is that , when the expansion is written in the form ( [ 4.3 ] ) , the various coefficients @xmath289 , @xmath231 , _ etc .",
    "_ , are regular functions of @xmath0 , which are continuous at @xmath28 .",
    "the structure ( [ 4.3 ] ) proves the result we wanted , namely the fact that the ir parts of the integrals in @xmath0 dimensions , @xmath612,\\ ] ] admits when @xmath264 the same value as the one given in @xmath41 dimensions by the original definition of the finite part fp ( in @xmath41 dimensions ) .",
    "that is to say , the two operations of taking the fp and the limit @xmath264 commute .",
    "indeed , the definition ( [ b15 ] ) of the @xmath0-dimensional fp operation yields @xmath613 so that @xmath614 on the other hand , if we interchange the order of the two operations , we must first consider the limit when @xmath264 of ( [ 4.3 ] ) , namely @xmath615 and then , by applying the usual fp operation in @xmath41 dimensions , we must discard the poles @xmath616 and evaluate the remainder at @xmath184 , thus @xmath617 = c_0^{(3)}\\,,\\ ] ] which is the same result as found in ( [ 4.5 ] ) .",
    "this shows that all the ir terms , formally depending on the boundary of the integral at infinity , notably all those discussed in sec .",
    "ivd of @xcite , give exactly zero in the difference between dr and the phs regularization .",
    "their contribution to the multipole moments has already been taken into account in ref .",
    "this shows also that the outer - zone part of the last term in the expression of the moment , eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) , which is proportional to @xmath618 , is actually zero in the present formalism since it is zero in @xmath41 dimensions .",
    "as we have discussed in sec .",
    "[ secva ] , the end result of the dimensional regularization ( dr ) is simply given by the sum of the pure - hadamard - schwartz ( phs ) regularization and the `` _ _ difference _ _ '' that we have investigated in the general analysis of sec .",
    "now the phs regularization of the 3pn mass dipole and quadrupole moments of point particles binaries has already been computed in our previous work @xcite , in which the end result of the hadamard regularization ( hr ) was obtained as the sum of the phs result and of some specific ambiguity part parametrized by three ambiguity parameters . in the present section",
    "we construct the dr result and impose that it is _ physically equivalent _ to the hr one given in @xcite .",
    "as we shall show , this requirement will permit us to uniquely determine the ambiguity parameters .",
    "let us first state the end result of @xcite concerning the 3pn mass quadrupole moment as computed with hr .",
    "we denote it by @xmath619 ; see eqs .",
    "( 5.9)(5.10 ) in @xcite for its complete expression in the center - of - mass frame . in the present paper",
    "we shall not need the explicit formula for the moment ( which includes many complicated coefficients ) , but simply its structure , made of the sum of the phs moment and some quite simple ambiguous contribution containing three and only three ambiguity parameters .",
    "the ambiguous part reads @xmath620 = \\frac{44}{3}\\,\\frac{g_n^2\\,m_1 ^ 3}{c^6}\\biggl[\\left(\\hat{\\xi } + \\hat{\\kappa } \\frac{m_1+m_2}{m_1}\\right ) y_1^{\\langle i}a_1^{j\\rangle } + \\hat{\\zeta } \\,v_1^{\\langle i}v_1^{j\\rangle}\\biggr ] + 1\\leftrightarrow 2\\,,\\ ] ] where @xmath621 and @xmath622 are the two masses , @xmath623 , @xmath624 and @xmath625 are the position , coordinate velocity and coordinate acceleration of the particle 1 ( @xmath553 denotes the same for the particle 2 ) , and where the angular brackets surrounding indices mean the stf projection . all the quantities in ( [ amb ] ) are defined in @xmath41 dimensions ; @xmath313 is newton s constant , related to @xmath312 in @xmath0 dimensions by eq .",
    "( [ gn ] ) . obviously , since ( [ amb ] ) is already of order 3pn ( _ cf .",
    "_ the factor @xmath464 ) , the acceleration @xmath625 is simply given by the usual newtonian value ( in @xmath41 dimensions ) .",
    "the expression ( [ amb ] ) contains three ambiguity parameters @xmath626 .",
    "these are the ones which would be defined with respect the phs regularization . however , the ambiguity parameters were in fact defined earlier in ref .",
    "@xcite , which had adopted a different hadamard - type regularization , called `` hybrid '' , instead of the phs one . in general , where @xmath627 is the partie finie of a singular function @xmath525 at the point @xmath512 .",
    "( in this respect , the hybrid regularization is like the extended hadamard regularization defined in @xcite . )",
    "this introduces also some differences in the case of non - compact support integrals , between the `` case - by - case '' integration followed in @xcite and the systematic phs regularization of these integrals adopted in @xcite . ] accordingly , the phs ambiguity parameters @xmath626 differ from their hybrid counterparts in @xcite , which were denoted there @xmath628 .",
    "the result , which constituted a powerful check of the computations of @xcite , is that    [ hatamb]@xmath629    in the present paper we prefer to stick to the original definition of the parameters @xmath628 , since these have already been used in the computation of the 3pn binary orbital phasing @xcite and in the discussion of the efficiency of the 3pn templates ( see _ e.g. _ @xcite ) .",
    "hence the final outcome from hr for the 3pn mass quadrupole moment of the binary ( moving on a general , not necessarily circular , orbit ) is written as @xmath630= i_{ij}^{(\\mathrm{phs})}\\bigl[r_1',\\,r_2',\\,r_0\\bigr ] + \\delta i_{ij}\\bigl[\\xi+ \\frac{1}{22},\\,\\kappa,\\,\\zeta+ \\frac{9}{110}\\bigr].\\ ] ] the phs part , first term on the rhs , is free of the ambiguities @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 , but depends on the three regularization scales @xmath631 , @xmath632 and @xmath182 .",
    "first , @xmath182 is merely the scale we have introduced in the general mpm formalism , see ( [ rtilde ] ) in sec .",
    "[ seciiia ] , and which then appears in the definition of the source multipole moments in sec .",
    "[ seciiic ] .",
    "this scale will disappear when we relate the asymptotic waveform to the local matter distribution for general extended sources . the other scales @xmath631 and @xmath632 are specific to the application to the case of systems of point particles and come from regularizing self - field effects .",
    "_ by definition _ of the ambiguity parameters these scales are taken to be the _ same _ as the two scales that appear in the final expression of the 3pn equations of motion in harmonic coordinates computed in refs .",
    "@xcite . and",
    "@xmath4 depend on this choice ; see @xcite for discussions . ]",
    "they came from the regularization of poisson - type integrals in the equations of motion , where they can be interpreted as some infinitesimal radial distances used as cut - offs when the field point tends to the singularities .",
    "it should be noted that @xmath633 and @xmath634 are `` unphysical '' , in the sense that they can be arbitrarily modified ( though they can never be removed ) by a coordinate transformation of the `` bulk '' metric outside the particles @xcite , or , more consistently when we consider the renormalization which follows the regularization , by suitable shifts of the particles world - lines @xcite .    to get the dr result",
    "we must augment the phs result @xmath635 $ ] computed for any choice of hadamard regularization scales @xmath636 entering eq .",
    "( [ pf ] ) , by the corresponding difference @xmath637 $ ] , which is made of the sum of all the contributions @xmath565 , eq .  ( [ dhres ] ) , computed for all the individual non - compact support terms in the 3pn expression of the source quadrupole moment deduced from the explicit formulas given in sec .",
    "[ seciv ] .",
    "hence this difference reads @xmath638",
    "= \\sum_{\\substack{\\text{non - compact}\\\\ \\text{terms in $ i_{ij}$ } } } \\mathcal{d}h\\bigl[s_1,\\,s_2;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr].\\ ] ] the sum in the rhs runs over all the non - compact support terms excluding those which are in a form such that they depend only on the ir behavior of the integral ; indeed these terms do not contribute to the difference ( see sec .",
    "[ secvb ] ) .",
    "we recall also that in the calculation of the difference we do not have to take into account the compact - support terms , nor the distributional parts of the derivatives since they are already included in the phs result . in ( [ sumdiff ] ) we indicated that the difference depends both on the constants @xmath639 and @xmath485 associated with dr , and on the two scales @xmath547 , @xmath548 which were introduced into the hadamard partie finie ( [ pf ] ) .",
    "the dr result is then @xmath640 = i_{ij}^{(\\mathrm{phs } ) } \\bigl[s_1,\\,s_2,\\,r_0\\bigr]+\\mathcal{d}i_{ij}\\bigl[s_1,\\,s_2;\\ , \\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr].\\ ] ] the choice of hadamard regularization length scales @xmath547 , @xmath548 in eq .",
    "( [ iijdr ] ) is arbitrary because , as is easily checked @xmath547 , @xmath548 _ cancel out _ between the two terms in the rhs of ( [ iijdr ] ) , so that , as it should be , @xmath641 depends only on the dr characteristics @xmath226 and @xmath485 ( and also on @xmath182 which belongs to our general multipole moment formalism , and is in fact irrelevant for the present discussion ) . because of this independence on the choice of the scales @xmath547 , @xmath548 , we can choose them to be identical to the two specific length scales @xmath631 , @xmath632 entering the 3pn equations of motion .",
    "therefore we can rewrite eq .",
    "( [ iijdr ] ) as @xmath642 = i_{ij}^{(\\mathrm{phs } ) } \\bigl[r'_1,\\,r'_2,\\,r_0\\bigr]+\\mathcal{d}i_{ij}\\bigl [ r'_1,\\,r'_2;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr].\\ ] ]    let us now impose the _ physical equivalence _ between the dr result ( [ iijdr ] ) and the corresponding final hr result ( [ iijh ] ) containing the ambiguity parameters @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 . in doing this identification , we must remember , from the work on the 3pn equations of motion @xcite , that the `` bare '' particle positions , @xmath643 and @xmath644 , entering the dr result differ from their hadamard counterparts , say @xmath645 and @xmath646 , entering the equations of motion of @xcite , by some ( purely spatial ) _ shifts of the world - lines _ , _",
    "i.e. _ ,    [ shiftworldline]@xmath647    these shifts have been uniquely determined in ref .",
    "@xcite and denoted there by @xmath648 and @xmath649 ( see eqs .  ( 1.13 ) and ( 6.41)(6.43 ) in @xcite ) . in the present work ,",
    "we denote them by @xmath650 and @xmath651 in order to avoid any confusion with the name of the ambiguity parameter @xmath3 .",
    "these shifts of the world - lines are crucial and must be taken into account when comparing the dr and hr results .",
    "let us insist that the shifts in eqs .",
    "( [ shiftworldline ] ) are those which ensured the equivalence between the dr and hr results for the equations of motion . having made contact in @xcite between the renormalization scales entering the two regularization schemes in the context of the 3pn equations of motion , we must , by consistency , employ them to compare the dr and hr results for the 3pn multipole moments .",
    "the names @xmath652 come from the fact that the shifts permit to _ renormalize _ the dr result for the equations of motion , in the sense that all the poles @xmath16 appearing in the @xmath0-dimensional equations of motion were finally absorbed into the new definition of the world - lines .",
    "a non trivial check of our present calculations will be to verify that the _ same _ shifts allow one to get _ finite _ ( when @xmath2 ) final expressions for _ all _ the multipole moments , when expressed in terms of @xmath652 .",
    "note that the definition of the shifts corresponds to a _ non - minimal subtraction_. this non - minimality was needed to connect the dr result to the two - parameter _ class _ of hr results parametrized by arbitrary values of the scales @xmath631 and @xmath632 ( see @xcite for a discussion ) .",
    "hence the shifts @xmath650 and @xmath651 depend on @xmath631 and @xmath632 ( respectively ) .",
    "we shall comment more on the renormalization in sec .",
    "[ secvii ] .",
    "the precise expression of the shift is @xmath653 \\mathbf{a}_1\\,,\\ ] ] together with the shift of the other world - line obtained by @xmath553 . here",
    ", @xmath654 denotes the _ three - dimensional _ newtonian acceleration @xmath655 , where @xmath656 and @xmath657 [ _ i.e. _ , @xmath654 is the same quantity as in eq .",
    "( [ amb ] ) ] , and @xmath313 correspondingly denotes the _ three - dimensional _ newtonian constant . the expression ( [ shift ] ) seems to differ from the one given by eq .",
    "( 1.13 ) in @xcite , but this is because we have used in ( [ shift ] ) the newtonian acceleration @xmath654 in @xmath41 dimensions , while eq .",
    "( 1.13 ) in @xcite has been written with the help of the @xmath0-dimensional analogue @xmath658 .",
    "we have    [ a1d]@xmath659\\right ) \\mathbf{a}_1^{(d=3 ) } + \\mathcal{o}\\left(\\varepsilon^2\\right)\\,.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    here we used @xmath660 , and @xmath661/\\pi^{(d-2)/2}= 1-\\frac{1}{2}\\varepsilon\\ln\\overline{q}+\\mathcal{o } \\left(\\varepsilon^2\\right)$ ] , where @xmath662 with @xmath663 denoting the euler constant .",
    "evidently , since the shifts are at 3pn order , the modification of the mass quadrupole moment brought about by the latter shifts ( in the sense @xmath664 \\equiv i_{ij}[\\mathbf{y}^\\mathrm{ren } ] + \\delta_{\\bm{\\eta } } i_{ij}$ ] ) simply reads @xmath665 where we recall the fact that the newtonian limit of the quadrupole in any dimension @xmath0 takes the standard expression @xmath666 , see eq .",
    "( [ newtonian ] ) .",
    "the physical equivalence between the dr and hr results simply means that we require that the full dr quadrupole moment , computed for the `` bare '' particle positions entering the dr delta - function source , @xmath667 $ ] , coincides ( when @xmath264 , and for the correct , looked - for values of @xmath3 , @xmath4 , @xmath5 ) with the hr result @xmath668 $ ] . as said above , the particle positions @xmath669 entering the hr result must be identified with the `` renormalized '' dr positions @xmath670 introduced in eqs .",
    "( [ shiftworldline ] ) : @xmath671 .",
    "re - expressing the dr multipole moment in terms of the particle arguments @xmath672 , this requirement then leads to equating @xmath673 = \\lim_{\\varepsilon\\rightarrow 0}\\left [ i_{ij}^{(\\mathrm{dr})}\\bigl[r_0;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0;\\ , \\mathbf{y}_1^\\mathrm{ren},\\ , \\mathbf{y}_2^\\mathrm{ren}\\bigr ] + \\delta_{\\bm{\\eta}(r_1',\\,r_2 ' ; \\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0)}i_{ij}\\right].\\ ] ] in other words , this equivalence is between hr and the `` renormalized '' result from dr .",
    "we find that the poles @xmath674 separately present in the two terms in the brackets of ( [ equivdrhr ] ) cancel , so that the physical , renormalized , dr quadrupole moment , defined as the rhs of ( [ equivdrhr ] ) , is _ finite _ when @xmath2 and given by the limit shown.$ ] . in particular , the original , bare quadrupole moment is also _",
    "finite _ as @xmath264 ( when keeping fixed @xmath670 in taking the limit ) . ]",
    "let us now substitute into eq .",
    "( [ equivdrhr ] ) the expressions of the dr and hr quadrupole moments , respectively given by ( [ iijdr ] ) and ( [ iijh ] ) above .",
    "[ we henceforth assume that @xmath641 on the lhs of eq .",
    "( [ iijdr ] ) is evaluated for @xmath675 .",
    "] since , as we have seen , both the hr and the dr results have been expressed in terms of their core part , given by the phs regularization , we see that , when making their comparison in ( [ equivdrhr ] ) , we shall be able to remove the phs part , which is common to both sides of the equation . in this way , we obtain a relation for the ambiguity part @xmath676 of the hr quadrupole moment in terms of known quantities , _ viz . _ @xmath677 = \\lim_{\\varepsilon\\rightarrow 0 } \\bigl(\\mathcal{d}i_{ij}\\bigl[r_1',\\,r_2 ' ; \\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr]+\\,\\delta_{\\bm{\\eta}(r_1',\\,r_2 ' ; \\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0)}i_{ij}\\bigr)\\,.\\ ] ] we must now insert into ( [ equamb ] ) the concrete result of the detailed computation of the difference @xmath678 , for all the non - compact - support terms in the explicit expression of the moment derived in sec .",
    "[ secv ] , and following the recipe provided by eq .",
    "( [ dhres ] ) .",
    "the computation of @xmath679 was performed by means of computer - aided algebraic manipulations , using the _ mathematica _ software . the final result for",
    "@xmath678 reads [ modulo the neglect of @xmath568 terms ] @xmath680 & = & \\frac{g_n^2\\,m_1 ^ 3}{c^6 } \\biggl[\\left(-\\frac{22}{2\\varepsilon}-\\frac{220}{9 } + \\frac{22}{3}\\ln\\left ( \\frac{r_{12}\\,{r'}_1 ^ 2\\,\\overline{q}^{3/2}}{\\ell_0 ^ 3}\\right)\\right ) y_1^{\\langle i}a_1^{j\\rangle }",
    "-\\frac{86}{45 } \\,v_1^{\\langle i}v_1^{j\\rangle}\\biggr ] \\nonumber\\\\ & + & 1\\leftrightarrow 2\\,,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] with the notation already used in ( [ shift ] ) and ( [ a1d ] ) .",
    "we then modify the result by including the effect of the particular shift which is given by eqs .",
    "( [ shift ] ) and ( [ deltaetaiij ] ) .",
    "thanks to this shift we see that the dependence of ( [ rawdiff ] ) on the constants @xmath631 , @xmath632 , @xmath226 and @xmath485 is cancelled out .",
    "more precisely , we find that the rhs of eq .",
    "( [ equamb ] ) exactly takes the form of a particular instance of the general ambiguity term ( [ amb ] ) , namely @xmath681+\\,\\delta_{\\bm{\\eta}(r_1',\\,r_2 ' ; \\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0)}i_{ij}\\bigr)\\ , = \\delta i_{ij}\\bigl[-\\frac{9451}{9240},\\,0,\\,-\\frac{43}{330}\\bigr]\\,,\\ ] ] which yields the following constraint ( equivalent to three independent equations ) to be satisfied by the three ambiguity parameters @xmath682 : @xmath683 = \\delta i_{ij}\\bigl[-\\frac{9451}{9240},\\,0,\\,-\\frac{43}{330}\\bigr]\\,.\\ ] ] this immediately gives the following values for the ambiguity parameters ,    [ resamb]@xmath684    which finally provide an unambiguous determination of the 3pn radiation field of compact binaries by dr . as we reviewed in the introduction , eqs .",
    "( [ resamb ] ) represent the end result of dr , but in fact the results for each of the parameters @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 have also been obtained by means of an independent calculation .",
    "indeed , @xmath685 has been shown to be a consequence of the poincar invariance of the formalism @xcite ( we give also an alternative , @xmath0-dimensional derivation of this result in sec .",
    "[ secviii ] below ) , the value @xmath686 was deduced from the comparison between the dipole moment and the center - of - mass position within hr @xcite ( the latter test is equivalent to the one we shall perform below with the mass dipole in dr ) , and finally we shall be able to check that @xmath17 in sec .",
    "[ secvii ] . happens to be related to the previous one for the equation - of - motion related ambiguity parameter @xmath11 by a simple cyclic permutation of digits : compare @xmath687 ]      the mass - dipole moment @xmath688 is quite interesting to consider because it satisfies a conservation law : @xmath689 , where @xmath690 is the total momentum , and , as such , it can be derived directly from the binary s _ equations of motion _ ( instead of a _ wave generation _ formalism ) , as being linked to the conserved quantity @xmath691 associated with the boost symmetry of the hamiltonian or the lagrangian of the binary motion .",
    "indeed , the mass dipole moment is in fact nothing but the _ center - of - mass _ vector @xmath692 of the system of particles . and the center - of - mass vector @xmath693 can be thought of as being a consequence of the equivalence principle between gravitational and inertial masses , @xmath694 . indeed , @xmath695 while @xmath696 .",
    "( the equivalence principle is automatically incorporated into the present formalism , since the motion of the point particles is geodesic , see @xcite . ) ] now , the center of mass vector of point particles binaries is already known at 3pn order .",
    "its explicit expression was derived both in adm coordinates @xcite and in harmonic coordinates @xcite , eq .  ( 4.5 ) there ; see also its implicit derivation in harmonic coordinates in ref .",
    "[ when deriving a 3pn conserved quantity we neglect the 2.5pn radiation - reaction contribution to the equations of motion .",
    "] we thus have the possibility of an excellent verification of our calculations , since the end result we shall obtain for the 3pn mass dipole moment @xmath688 in dr _",
    "should _ perfectly match with the 3pn center - of - mass @xmath693 . in our previous paper , ref .",
    "@xcite , we have in fact already verified that @xmath697 within the hr scheme , in the sense that we _ required _ that @xmath697 holds , and then we deduced from this requirement the value of a particular combination of ambiguity parameters , namely @xmath686 . in the present section we shall directly show that @xmath697 in dr , without any fine tuning of ambiguity parameters like in hr .",
    "first of all , let us recall from @xcite and the discussion in @xcite that in the present formalism the conserved mass dipole moment @xmath688 is given by a slightly more complicated expression than the non - conserved moments @xmath159 , with @xmath698 .",
    "namely we have @xmath699 , where @xmath700 is given by the same expression as for @xmath159 but taken for @xmath701 , and where @xmath702 represents a certain correction to it , which is given , together with the similar corrections present in the mass @xmath703 and current dipole @xmath704 , in eqs .",
    "( 2.22 ) of @xcite ( in @xmath41 dimensions ) .",
    "in @xcite we proved that the correction @xmath702 gives _ zero _ in the dipole moment _ at 3pn order _ , so that @xmath705 .",
    "now , @xmath702 is in the form of integrals at infinity ( _ cf . _",
    "the factor @xmath179 in front of the integrals in eqs .",
    "( 2.22 ) of @xcite ) , and we have proved in sec .",
    "[ secvb ] that for such integrals the results in hr and dr are the same .",
    "hence we deduce that @xmath702 is also zero when applying dr and that @xmath705 is also true in @xmath0 dimensions , modulo @xmath706 terms .",
    "therefore , we need only discuss here the dr calculation of the main part of the dipole moment , namely @xmath700 .",
    "the 3pn mass dipole moment @xmath700 in hr is ambiguous , but the structure of the ambiguity part is very simple , as it contains one and only one ambiguity parameter @xmath707 , which turned out to be given by the particular combination @xmath708 of the parameters @xmath709 and @xmath710 which appeared previously in eq .",
    "( [ amb ] ) .",
    "see sec .",
    "vb in @xcite for details .",
    "the structure of the ambiguity in the dipolar case is @xmath711 = \\frac{22}{3}\\left(\\hat{\\xi}+\\hat{\\kappa}\\right ) \\frac{g_n^2\\,m_1 ^ 3}{c^6}\\,a_1^{i } + 1\\leftrightarrow 2\\,.\\ ] ] using the link we have found in ( [ hatamb ] ) we can then write the hr result for the dipole moment in terms of the combination @xmath15 of the original ambiguity parameters in @xcite , hence @xmath712=i_{i}^{(\\mathrm{phs})}\\bigl[r_1',\\,r_2'\\bigr ] + \\delta i_{i}\\bigl[\\xi+\\kappa+\\frac{1}{22}\\bigr],\\ ] ] which is the dipolar analogue of eq .",
    "( [ iijh ] ) . however , a minor difference with ( [ iijh ] ) is that the 3pn dipole moment happens to be independent of the cut - off scale @xmath182 .",
    "as we said above , the value of @xmath15 could be determined in @xcite by imposing that the hr result ( [ iijh ] ) is in agreement with the 3pn center - of - mass position given in @xcite .",
    "let us now investigate what happens when using dr . like for the case of the quadrupole moment , the result for the dipole moment in dr is given as the sum of the phs dipole and of the difference @xmath713 , which is made out of the sum of all the contributions of the non - compact support terms ( excluding as usual the surface terms at infinity ) present in the explicit formulas of sec .",
    "[ seciv ] , say @xmath714 = \\sum_{\\substack{\\text{non - compact}\\\\ \\text{terms in $ i_{i}$ } } } \\mathcal{d}h\\bigl[s_1,\\,s_2;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr],\\ ] ] where @xmath547 , @xmath548 are the two hr scales in the partie - finie integral ( [ pf ] ) , @xmath226 and @xmath485 are the dr scales , and each of the @xmath565 s are computed using eq .",
    "( [ dhres ] ) .",
    "hence ,    [ iidr]@xmath715 & = & i_{i}^{(\\mathrm{phs})}\\bigl[s_1,\\,s_2\\bigr]+\\mathcal{d}i_{i}\\bigl [ s_1,\\,s_2;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr]\\label{iidra}\\\\ & = & i_{i}^{(\\mathrm{phs})}\\bigl[r'_1,\\,r'_2\\bigr ] + \\mathcal{d}i_{i}\\bigl [ r'_1,\\,r'_2;\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr],\\label{iidrb}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where , like in the case of the quadrupole moment , we have taken advantage of the fact that the constants @xmath716 cancel out from the two terms in the rhs of ( [ iidra ] ) , to rewrite the result in terms of the specific length scales @xmath717 which parametrize the 3pn equations of motion in @xcite .",
    "the last step is to renormalize the dr result by absorbing the poles in a spatial shift of the two particles world - lines . of course",
    ", we must use the same shift vectors as in eq .",
    "( [ shift ] ) , and these result in the following modification of the dipole moment , @xmath718 which is indeed checked to cancel the poles @xmath16 of the `` bare '' dr dipole moment , so that the following limit when @xmath2 is finite , @xmath719 = \\lim_{\\varepsilon\\rightarrow 0}\\left [ i_{i}^{(\\mathrm{dr})}\\bigl[\\,\\varepsilon,\\,\\ell_0\\bigr ] + \\delta_{\\bm{\\eta}(r_1',\\,r_2 ' ; \\varepsilon,\\ell_0)}i_{i}\\right]\\,.\\ ] ] this represents our final `` renormalized '' dr dipole moment . the final result ( [ mi ] ) for the dipole moment depends on the scales @xmath633 and @xmath634 .",
    "we recall that this dependence does not correspond to any physical ambiguity , since @xmath633 and @xmath634 have the character of gauge quantities .    finally , after having performed the detailed calculation of the `` difference '' ( using the same algebraic computer programs as for the quadrupole ) , and having added this difference to the result for the phs part which was obtained earlier in ref .",
    "@xcite , we found that the renormalized dr moment @xmath688 given by eq .",
    "( [ mi ] ) , is in complete agreement with the conserved center - of - mass position @xmath693 associated with the conservative part of the 3pn equations of motion , namely @xmath720 = g_{i}\\bigl[r_1',\\,r_2'\\bigr],\\ ] ] where @xmath693 is explicitly given by eq .",
    "( 4.5 ) in ref .",
    "we view this test as an important verification of our method and our detailed calculations .",
    "we have given above the final results obtained by combining the dr computation of the singular ( @xmath721 ) contributions to the multipole moments , coming from the vicinity of the point masses , with the phs results of ref .",
    "this way of presenting our results is in close correspondence with the actual calculations we did , but it has the defect of somewhat hiding the logical structure of our dr results . in this section , we shall go back to basic methodological questions and explain in more details the logic behind dr .",
    "we shall also show how the examination of the structure of the dr results allows one to perform several checks of these results .",
    "let us first recall that ref .",
    "@xcite presented a general method for dealing with the gravitational interaction of two ( non spinning ) _ compact _ bodies , _",
    "i.e. _ , bodies whose radii are of the same order as their gravitational radii . at the time , the main motivation for considering this situation was the accurate relativistic description of binary pulsar systems ( _ i.e. _ , binary neutron stars ) . today",
    ", we have the additional motivation of accurately describing not only the motion but also the gravitational radiation from binary black holes ( as well as binary neutron stars , or mixed black - hole neutron - star systems ) .",
    "reference  @xcite did not assume from the start a formal `` point mass '' representation of the two compact bodies but used instead a _ matching _ approach which combined two different approximation methods : ( i ) an `` external perturbation scheme '' , _",
    "i.e. _ , an iterative , weak - field ( post - minkowskian ) approximation scheme valid in a domain outside two world - tubes containing the two bodies , and ( ii ) an `` internal perturbation scheme '' describing the small perturbations of each body by the far - field of its companion . a useful outcome of this matching approach was a proof that to a very high approximation , the internal structures of the compact bodies were _ effaced _ when seen in the external scheme .",
    "more precisely , @xcite ( sec .  5 there ) found that the internal structures affected the equations of motion only starting at the 5pn level , through a term which is of fractional order @xmath722 ^ 5 $ ] . here",
    "@xmath723 is a dimensionless love number describing the quadrupolar deformation of one of the compact bodies under the influence of the tidal field generated by its companion .",
    "this result can be simply understood from a well - known newtonian argument on the influence on the orbital motion of the newtonian quadrupole moments induced by tidal interaction between the two compact objects ( see _ e.g. _ sec .",
    "1.2 in @xcite ) .",
    "indeed , the quadrupole moments scale as @xmath724 , where @xmath46 is the typical size of the objects , hence in the case of compact objects for which @xmath725 we have in fact @xmath726 , which gives rise to the above mentioned correction to the equations of motion ( and orbital phase ) at the 5pn order relatively to the newtonian acceleration .",
    "effacement result _ is the rationale for describing , up to 5pn order , two ( non spinning ) compact bodies in terms of two point masses .",
    "technically , this means representing the compact bodies by a `` skeleton '' made of two massive world - lines , _",
    "i.e. _ , by a point - particle action @xmath727 note that the previous reasoning suggests that , starting at the 5pn level , one will need to augment the effective action ( [ 6.1 ] ) by further terms , starting with a _ quadrupole - type _ addition to the _ monopole _ action ( [ 6.1 ] ) . at the 2.5pn level ,",
    "@xcite explicitly showed how to deal with a point - particle description of the type ( [ 6.1 ] ) by using riesz analytical continuation method to ( uniquely ) regularize the divergent integrals linked to the use of point particles in non - linear general relativity .",
    "it was also mentioned at the time @xcite that equivalent ( 2.5pn ) results could be obtained by using an analytic continuation of the space - time dimension @xmath33 , instead of a riesz - type analytic continuation .",
    "the derivation of the equations of motion at the 3pn level turned out to be technically complicated , but conceptually satisfactory .",
    "two independent works , @xcite and @xcite , succeeded in computing using hadamard - type regularizations most of the complicated non - linear integrals appearing at 3pn order except for a few of them , which turned out to be ambiguous because of the appearance of logarithmic divergencies at the 3pn order .",
    "then , two further independent works , @xcite and @xcite , showed that dimensional regularization gave unique , consistent answers , for the latter divergent integrals .",
    "a satisfactory check of the consistency of dr was indeed that these two independent calculations gave perfectly consistent final answers , though they were performed in _ different gauges _",
    ", by completely different methods .    in particular , it was found @xcite that , in arnowitt - deser - misner ( adm ) gauge , dr led to _",
    "finite _ equations of motion ( no poles @xmath16 ) , so that the full dynamics of the system could be described by an effective action obtained by adding to the @xmath0-dimensional adm - gauge - fixed gravitational action the usual action for point particles coupled to gravity , namely eq .",
    "( [ 6.1 ] ) above .",
    "all the quantities appearing in this adm plus point particle action have finite limiting values when @xmath2 .",
    "by contrast , it was found in @xcite that , in harmonic coordinates , dr led to equations of motion containing simple poles @xmath16 , but that those poles could be _",
    "renormalized away_. there are two ways of thinking of this renormalization .",
    "a first way is to add to the usual point - particle action ( [ 6.1 ] ) a counter - term describing a possible ( infinitesimal ) shift of the world - lines @xmath728 ( in other words a _ dipole _ term ) .",
    "then one shows that this dipolar counter - term is exactly what is needed to absorb the @xmath277 poles and to leave a finite answer for both the equations of motion and the bulk metric ( _ i.e. _ , the metric outside the world - lines ) .",
    "a second ( technically equivalent ) way is to use only the usual point - particle action ( [ 6.1 ] ) but to consider that the `` bare '' world - lines @xmath728 entering ( [ 6.1 ] ) can be decomposed in the way given by eq .  ( [ shiftworldline ] ) , as ( choosing a parametrization by the coordinate time , @xmath729 ) @xmath730 where @xmath670 is finite as @xmath278 , but where @xmath731 , though being formally `` small '' , namely of 3pn order , contains a pole part @xmath561 which absorbs all the poles appearing in the harmonic - coordinates calculations .",
    "summarizing , the explicit 3pn - level calculations of the equations of motion ( and of the pole part of the bulk metric , see sec .",
    "vi of @xcite ) have confirmed the effacement result of @xcite , _",
    "i.e. _ , technically , the soundness of describing two compact bodies by the simple effective action ( [ 6.1 ] )",
    ". however , they also showed that , at such a high non - linearity order , it is crucial to use a fully consistent , and gauge - invariant regularization method .",
    "dimensional regularization , which was invented precisely to preserve gauge invariance @xcite , is the method of choice to use in this respect .",
    "as a start let us explain how one might have described the results of sec .",
    "[ secvi ] for the mass multipole moments in terms of field - theory diagrams .",
    "classical diagrammatic representations of non - linear interactions in general relativity have been introduced and used in several works , notably in @xcite . in a previous paper of this series , ref .",
    "@xcite , we have used diagrams to clarify the structure of the various contributions to the equations of motion of two point particles .",
    "let us do the same here for the mass multipole moments given by ( [ ilexpr2 ] ) .",
    "we represent the basic delta - function sources entering @xmath315 as two world - lines , and each ( post - minkowskian ) propagator @xmath732 as a dotted line . the various post - minkowskian potentials @xmath733 , @xmath734 , @xmath735 , @xmath736 , @xmath737 , _ etc .",
    "_ , entering the effective sources @xmath453 , @xmath462 , @xmath463 [ see sec .",
    "[ seciv ] ] can then be represented by drawing some dotted lines which start at the `` bare '' sources @xmath502 , @xmath503 , @xmath504 , join at some intermediate vertices , corresponding to the non - linear couplings entering the definition of the non - linear potentials [ such as the non - compact part of @xmath738 given by ( [ wij ] ) ] , and end at the field point @xmath739 .",
    "the simpler `` linear potentials '' , such as @xmath733 or the `` compact '' part of @xmath740 ( _ i.e. _ , the part generated by @xmath504 ) , are just represented by one dotted line joining a world - line to the field point @xmath739 .",
    "a product of potentials entering the effective sources @xmath741 , such as @xmath742 is represented by juxtaposing the diagrams of each potential . [ in this simplified diagrammatic representation we do not explicitly indicate the various derivative operators which enter as `` vertex factors '' at the common field point @xmath739 .",
    "however , we take care of them when they are important for the convergence properties of the diagram . ] finally , we can represent the inclusion of the `` multipolar factors '' , such as @xmath539 , by adding a circled cross @xmath743 .",
    "it is then understood that one integrates over the `` crossed vertex '' , _",
    "i.e. _ , the field point .    using such a representation , the mass multipole moments are given by the sum of many diagrams .",
    "note first that , when comparing the diagrams representing the calculation of the 3pn multipole moment to the diagrams entering the 3pn equations of motion in @xcite , one finds that the former have a less complicated structure .",
    "indeed , ref .",
    "@xcite has shown that the 3pn equations of motion involve diagrams containing up to _ four _ independent source points ( located on the world - lines ) , and up to _ five _ intermediate propagators ( _ i.e. _ , five dotted lines ) : see figs .",
    "24 in @xcite .",
    "by contrast , the 3pn multipole moments only involve ( if we treat separately , as was systematically done , the terms that can be transformed into surface integrals at infinity ) diagrams containing up to _ three _ source points , and _ four _ propagators .",
    "examining the types of singular integrals corresponding to the possible diagrams , one then finds the same rule of thumb which was found to hold in @xcite for the more complicated diagrams entering the equations of motion : namely , the only dangerously , and we refer to them as the `` dangerous '' terms . ]",
    "diverging diagrams are those containing ( at least ) three propagator lines that can simultaneously shrink to zero size , as a subset of vertices coalesce together on one of the world - lines . but as there are , in the present problem , at most three source points , this means that the dangerously divergent diagrams are only those represented in fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] below ( or their `` mirror '' image obtained by exchanging @xmath744 ) .     by dotted lines , the source points by bullets , and",
    "the @xmath743 symbol means a multiplication by a multipolar factor , such as @xmath539 , together with a spatial integration @xmath745 . ]",
    "these diagrams are also characterized by the fact that they involve , as post - minkowskian diagrams ( _ i.e. _ , before explicitly performing the pn expansion , or the repeated time derivatives , which can introduce the acceleration of the world - line ) , either @xmath746 or @xmath747 as explicit factor .",
    "this reasoning is confirmed by a scrutiny of the many explicit results reported in @xcite for separate pieces of the multipole moments . in the presentation of ref .",
    "@xcite ( which is less systematic than the more recent re - calculation of @xcite , but more explicit ) the dangerously divergent integrals ( in @xmath28 ) are essentially all the terms involving the objects @xmath748 , @xmath749 or @xmath750 , and these terms are all multiplied by @xmath746 .",
    "indeed , these objects are integrals of the type @xmath751 or @xmath752 , which are logarithmically divergent in @xmath28 , and lead to @xmath277 poles in @xmath753 .",
    "let us exhibit the explicit form of the terms , corresponding to the diagrams shown in fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] , which are responsible for the poles @xmath16 in the final result for the multipole moments .",
    "let us decompose , as in @xcite , the expression for @xmath159 in : ( i ) `` first - order scalar '' part @xmath754 ( linear in @xmath453 ) , ( ii ) second - order scalar part @xmath755 ( linear in @xmath756 ) , ( iii ) first - order vector part @xmath757 ( linear in @xmath758 ) , _",
    "etc_. one finds that the `` dangerous '' contributions to @xmath159 are contained only in @xmath754 , @xmath755 and @xmath757 .",
    "moreover , one finds that the velocity - dependent terms that generates poles @xmath561 in intermediate calculations all cancel out in the final result . before taking the limit @xmath759 .",
    "] we focus here for simplicity on the non - cancelled poles , which do not depend on velocities .",
    "hence , @xmath760 where one checks that among the many contributions generated by inserting eq .",
    "( [ sources ] ) into eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) the only potentially dangerous ones , in the static limit @xmath761 , @xmath762 , come from    [ 6.4 - 6]@xmath763 \\biggr\\},\\label{6.4}\\\\ \\mathrm{sii}_l^\\mathrm{danger } & = & \\frac{1}{2 ( 2\\ell + d)\\,\\pi\\ , f\\,g \\ , c^6 } \\,\\mathrm{fp } \\ , \\frac{d^2}{dt^2 } \\int d^d \\mathbf{x } \\,\\widetilde{r}^b\\ , \\widehat{x}_l \\biggl\\ { - \\vert\\mathbf{x}\\vert^2 \\ , \\hat w_{ij } \\ , \\partial_{ij } \\ , v \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\quad - ( 2\\ell + d ) \\ , v \\hat w - \\frac{1}{3 } \\ , \\frac{(2\\ell + d)(d-1)^2}{(d-2)^2 } \\",
    ", v^3 \\biggr\\},\\label{6.5}\\\\ \\mathrm{vi}_l^\\mathrm{danger } & = & - \\frac{4 ( 2\\ell + d-2 ) } { ( \\ell + d - 2)(2\\ell + d)\\ , \\pi \\ , f\\,g \\ , c^6 } \\,\\mathrm{fp } \\ , \\frac{d}{dt } \\int d^d \\mathbf{x } \\,\\widetilde{r}^b\\ , \\widehat x_{il } \\,\\biggl\\ { \\frac{1}{8 } \\ , \\frac{d(d-1)^2}{(d-2)^3 } \\ , v \\ , \\partial_t \\ , v \\ , \\partial_i \\ , v \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\quad - \\frac{(d-1)^2}{4(d-2)^2 } \\ , v_i \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v + \\ , \\frac{1}{4 } \\ , \\frac{d(d-1)}{(d-2)^2 } \\ , v_k \\ , \\partial_i \\ , v \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v + \\frac{d-1}{d-2 } \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v \\ , \\partial_i \\ , \\hat r_k \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\quad - \\ , \\hat w_{kl } \\ , \\partial_{kl } \\ , v_i + \\frac{d-1}{2(d-2 ) } \\ , \\partial_t \\ , \\hat w_{ik } \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v - \\partial_i \\ , \\hat w_{kl } \\ , \\partial_k \\ , v_{l } + \\ , \\partial_k \\ , \\hat w_{il } \\ , \\partial_{l } \\ , v_k \\biggr\\}. \\label{6.6}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where we set @xmath764 .",
    "note that the expression we used for @xmath755 in our calculations has been transformed , from the original form which is directly arising from the source terms given in eqs .",
    "( [ sources ] ) above , by operating by parts on the terms proportional to @xmath765 and @xmath766 .",
    "this was done to exactly parallel the calculation of ref .",
    "@xcite ( see for instance eq .",
    "( 3.4b ) there ) and thereby to reduce the problem of evaluating the dr result to a term - by - term difference between analogous singular integrands . as explained in sec .",
    "[ secvb ] , all the `` gradient terms '' generated when operating by parts are expressible in terms of surface integrals in the outer near - zone , and do not contribute to the difference between dr and phs .",
    "we have therefore suppressed most of these gradient terms in eqs .",
    "( [ 6.4 - 6 ] ) , except in eq .  ( [ 6.4 ] ) where , as an example and as a reminder of the presence of such terms , we have left the terms proportional to the laplacians of @xmath766 and @xmath767 .",
    "let us explicitly show on the example of @xmath768 that this term , though potentially dangerous , does not give rise to any pole .",
    "the linear potential @xmath477 is naturally decomposed into @xmath769 where @xmath770 is generated by the first particle , and @xmath771 by the second . in agreement with fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] the dangerous contributions are cubic in @xmath621 or cubic in @xmath622 . in particular , the dangerous pieces in any term containing @xmath766 are @xmath772 and @xmath773 .",
    "let us henceforth look only at the poles generated near the first world - line ( _ i.e. _ , @xmath774 ) . in dimensional regularization , it is perfectly legitimate to integrate by parts .",
    "this transforms the contribution @xmath775 into @xmath776 . using @xmath777",
    ", we see that the result is proportional to @xmath179 .",
    "as we shall see in detail below the remaining integral @xmath778 generates a pole @xmath16 .",
    "the contribution linear in @xmath779 yields therefore a result proportional to @xmath228 .",
    "but , by the definition of the @xmath0-dimensional finite part operation , one has @xmath780 , so that we have indeed checked the absence of pole generated by the _ a priori _ dangerous term @xmath781 .",
    "similarly for the term @xmath782 in ( [ 6.4 ] ) .",
    "let us consider the various remaining terms in the integrand of @xmath754 , eq .",

    "we start with the term @xmath783 , where @xmath784 denotes the so - called `` non compact '' piece of @xmath479 , _",

    "concludes that the term @xmath796 does not generate any pole .    only the second term on the rhs of ( [ 6.7 ] ) generates a pole @xmath16 which survives the finite part operation . by looking at the terms contained in the last bracket on the rhs of eq .",
    "( [ 6.4 ] ) one finds that the only dangerous integrands have the same form as the second term on the rhs of eq .",

    "as usual the only dangerous terms are those proportional to @xmath802 or @xmath803 .",

    "finally , we conclude that the _ dangerous _ terms in eq .",

    "let us now consider the dangerous terms in @xmath755 , eq .",
    "( [ 6.5 ] ) . in this case",
    "one must pay a careful attention to the dependence of the coefficients on the angular momentum index @xmath94 .",
    "indeed , it is important to note that there was no explicit dependence on @xmath94 in eq .",
    "( [ 6.11 ] ) apart from the factor @xmath539 .",
    "by contrast , the coefficients entering ( [ 6.5 ] ) explicitly depend on @xmath94 .",
    "since ( [ 6.5 ] ) has an overall factor @xmath811 , it is sufficient to use the leading pn approximations for @xmath479 and @xmath477 ; in view of our previous ( 1pn - accurate ) result ( [ 6.7 ] ) this means that we can use @xmath812 ( as usual we focus on the terms @xmath774 ) .",
    "the occurrence of an explicit laplacian allows us to re - express the first term on the rhs of ( [ 6.5 ] ) by integrating by parts .",
    "this leads to a term proportional to ( we keep only the coefficients depending on @xmath94 ) @xmath813 using @xmath814 we get a contribution of the form @xmath815 the pole part @xmath16 of the contribution ( [ 6.13 ] ) is generated by integrating in the vicinity of the first world - line .",
    "for such a local integral the ir - converging factor @xmath816 has no importance and we can take the analytic continuation @xmath817 directly in the ( localized ) integrand .",
    "this leads to the disappearance of the @xmath94-dependence in the factor appearing in ( [ 6.13 ] ) . as for the last two terms on the rhs of ( [ 6.5 ] )",
    ", one sees that the @xmath94-dependence cancels between the factor @xmath818 in front , and the factors @xmath819 multiplying the integrands @xmath820 and @xmath821 .",
    "finally , we conclude that the dangerous terms in @xmath755 are of the form @xmath822 the coefficient @xmath823 does not depend on @xmath94 ( like was the case for @xmath808 ) .",
    "the repeated time derivative in ( [ 6.14 ] ) can then be let to act on @xmath824 only ( modulo `` non dangerous '' terms ) yielding , in view of eq .",
    "( [ 6.10 ] ) , @xmath825 so that @xmath826 a similar study of the `` vector '' contribution @xmath757 , eq .
