    "the second term of ( [ 6.16 ] ) , with a coefficient denoted @xmath829 , is _ a priori _ more problematic .",
    "integrating by parts does not give a vanishing result ( because @xmath830 does not vanish ) .",
    "if present this term would have a complicated dependence on @xmath94 .",
    "however , the overall coefficient @xmath829 of this term is the sum of many individual contributions , and one finds that they _ all _ cancel out to yield @xmath831 , so that finally @xmath832    the result @xmath831 can be obtained either by explicit calculations in @xmath0 dimensions , using notably the explicit form of @xmath833 , namely ( to leading order ) @xmath834,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] or by considering the limiting case @xmath28 . in this limiting case , the poles @xmath16 are associated to logarithmically divergent integrals .",
    "looking at the 3-dimensional results given by ( 8.2c ) , ( 9.3j ) and ( 9.3k ) of ref .",
    "@xcite for @xmath757 , one indeed finds that the terms @xmath835 , corresponding to the @xmath836 limit of the second contribution in ( [ 6.16 ] ) , do cancel in the final result , though they appear in intermediate terms : see the first terms on the rhs of eqs .",
    "( 9.3j)(9.3k ) of @xcite with coefficients @xmath837 and @xmath838 respectively ( note a small misprint in ( 9.3k ) of @xcite : the overall factor @xmath839 should be understood as @xmath746 ) .",
    "note also that , in view of the general structure ( [ 6.16 ] ) derived above , it is enough to check the cancellation of these terms for the quadrupolar case @xmath840 to conclude that @xmath841 .    summarizing our results so far , we conclude , by adding ( [ 6.11 ] ) , ( [ 6.15 ] ) and ( [ 6.18 ] ) that the pole part @xmath774 in the @xmath94-th mass multipole moment is contained in @xmath842 with a final coefficient @xmath843 . by summing the various contributions",
    "one finds @xmath844 where the first term on the rhs is enough to discuss the residue of the pole @xmath16 .",
    "the result ( [ 6.20])([6.21 ] ) is the explicit expression of the dangerous part of the two diagrams of fig .",
    "let us now see explicitly why it is nicely renormalized away by using exactly the same dipole counter - term that was found necessary in @xcite .",
    "the pole generated by ( [ 6.20 ] ) can be seen , after integrating by parts the spatial gradient ( @xmath845 ) , as coming from an integral of the form @xmath846 where @xmath847 is a smooth function of @xmath510 ( at least near @xmath602 ) .",
    "taylor - expanding @xmath847 near @xmath602 one sees that the pole in ( [ 6.22 ] ) comes from the zero - th term @xmath848 which multiplies an integral proportional to @xmath849 where we recall that @xmath850 denotes the area of the @xmath851 dimensional sphere .",
    "therefore , in the limit @xmath264 , the integral ( [ 6.22 ] ) is asymptotically equivalent to @xmath852 this means that , when @xmath264 the integrand @xmath824 is asymptotically equivalent ( in the formal sense of distributions in @xmath0-dimensional space ) to @xmath853 inserting this result into ( [ 6.20 ] ) one concludes that the _ pole part _ ( due to the uv divergencies in the neighborhoods of @xmath512 and @xmath513 ) of the 3pn - accurate @xmath94-th mass multipole moment is given by @xmath854 if we compare ( [ 6.26 ] ) with the leading , newtonian approximation for @xmath159 , namely @xmath855 we see that the pole part ( [ 6.26 ] ) can be absorbed in a dipole - like modification [ @xmath856 of the mass density @xmath857 , or equivalently in a shift of the world - line position @xmath512 .",
    "more precisely , if we decompose the full @xmath512 ( henceforth called the `` bare '' @xmath512 ) as in eq .",
    "( [ 6.2 ] ) , with @xmath645 being finite as @xmath264 , but with @xmath650 designed to absorb the pole part ( [ 6.26 ] ) , one easily checks that one needs to define @xmath858 in order to renormalize away this pole .",
    "note that it was crucial to have no @xmath94-dependence of the coefficients in the dangerous part ( [ 6.20 ] ) in order to be able to renormalize away the _ infinite sequence _ of multipoles by means of the @xmath94-independent shift @xmath650 ( [ 6.28 ] ) .",
    "in addition , by inserting the numerical value ( [ 6.21 ] ) of the coefficient @xmath859 , one finds that the shift ( [ 6.28 ] ) needed to absorb the poles in the infinite sequence of multipole moments coincides with the shift obtained in @xcite by the requirement of renormalizing both the `` bulk metric '' and the equations of motion .",
    "more precisely , ref .",
    "@xcite found that the choice of the shift recalled above in eq .",
    "( [ shift ] ) [ and which contains ( [ 6.28 ] ) as its pole part ] allowed one not only to get a finite ( pole - less ) bulk metric and finite equations of motion , but that the equations of motion coincide ( when , and only when , @xmath860 ) with the harmonic - gauge equations of motion , parametrized by @xmath633 and @xmath634 , and derived using hr in refs .",
    "we recall that it is necessary to introduce some length scales @xmath633 and @xmath634 associated with the hr of logarithmically divergent integrals in harmonic gauge .    as we have shown here the dangerous divergencies associated with the vicinity of the _ first _ world - line",
    "are entirely contained in the diagrams shown in fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] , and , therefore , are proportional to @xmath746 , without any explicit dependence on the second mass @xmath622 .",
    "[ there is only an implicit dependence on @xmath622 _ via _ the fact that the acceleration @xmath654 is proportional to @xmath622 .",
    "but , at the level of the diagrams , @xmath654 must be considered as a pure characteristic of the first world - line .",
    "] as a consequence , we see in eq .",
    "( [ 6.28 ] ) that the dipole @xmath861 needed to subtract the poles is also proportional to @xmath746 .",
    "this simple algebraic fact immediately leads , without calculations , to the result that @xmath862 .",
    "indeed , the definition of the parameter @xmath4 in ref .",
    "@xcite , was to parametrize a conceivable _ a priori _ ambiguity , which is indeed allowed by the weak assumptions of @xcite , in the renormalization of the logarithmic divergencies of the type ( for the first particle ) @xmath863 where @xmath633 and @xmath547 are two possible choices of regularization length scales associated to the first particle , and where we have incorporated the factor @xmath746 associated to the divergences linked to @xmath512 .",
    "as ( [ 6.29 ] ) shows , the parameter @xmath4 corresponds to a mixing between diagrams with three legs on the first world - line ( as in fig .  [ fig1 ] ) and diagrams having two legs on the first world - line and one on the second . our diagrammatic study has shown that the latter diagrams have no dangerous divergencies , _",
    "i.e. _ , that they do not introduce any conceivable ambiguity ( even if we were working directly in @xmath28 , using hr ) .",
    "therefore we conclude that @xmath862 .",
    "the work of this section has shown that the pole in the @xmath94-th mass moment @xmath159 was given by eq .",
    "( [ 6.26 ] ) whose numerical coefficients contain _ no dependence on the value of _ @xmath94 .",
    "this proves , in particular , that the same shift ( [ 6.28 ] ) , or more precisely ( [ shift ] ) , yields finite values of both the quadrupole moment @xmath381 ( @xmath157 ) and the dipole moment @xmath688 ( @xmath864 ) . that the conserved mass dipole moment @xmath688 reads @xmath699 , where @xmath702 represents a certain correction term which , however , turns out not to contribute at the 3pn order ( see @xcite ) . ] as said above the mass dipole moment @xmath688 coincides with the arnowitt - deser - misner ( adm ) dipole moment or _ center - of - mass _ position @xmath693 , such that @xmath865 is conserved , where @xmath690 denotes the total adm linear momentum .",
    "the comparison between @xmath688 and @xmath693 in @xcite permitted to fix the value of the combination @xmath866 within the hr scheme , under the assumption that the regularization scales @xmath547 and @xmath548 represent some unknown but _ fixed _ constants , related to @xmath633 and @xmath634 by some definite equations , and in particular take the same values for both the computations of the quadrupole @xmath381 and the dipole @xmath688 .",
    "this assumption worked well in the case of the hr computation of the multipole moments , but failed to work when it was tried to assume that the same scales @xmath547 and @xmath548 are _ also _ those which entered the hr computation of the equations of motion @xcite .",
    "indeed , the work on the equations of motion used for the relation between @xmath547 and @xmath633 , for the divergences linked to the first particle , @xmath867 where @xmath11 was later determined to have a non - zero value , @xmath868 .",
    "such a link is clearly incompatible with ( [ 6.29 ] ) and the value we have found for @xmath17 .",
    "this means that one is not _ a priori _ allowed to assume , when using hr , that the scales @xmath547 and @xmath548 represent always the same scales , fixed once and for all , and which can be used in different bodies of calculations . in this respect",
    "the hr is not a fully consistent regularization scheme .",
    "however , it can nevertheless be applied if one accepts that its incompleteness results in the appearance of some unknown scales @xmath547 and @xmath548 ( generally in front of a few terms only ) , which can take different values , depending on the type of calculation one is doing .",
    "by contrast we have proved in sec .",
    "[ secvib ] above that the same value of @xmath3 is consistent , in dr , with the renormalized results of both @xmath381 and @xmath869 .",
    "this result constitutes evidently a solid confirmation of the value @xmath870 .      to conclude our discussion of the diagrammatic approach to the renormalization of the poles which appear in harmonic gauge ,",
    "let us briefly comment on the recent claim @xcite that these poles require the introduction of new terms in the effective action describing compact ( but extended ) objects , beyond eq .",
    "( [ 6.1 ] ) and the dipole term we found above , linked to the shift ( [ 6.2 ] ) . the modified effective action proposed in ref .",
    "@xcite has the form @xmath871 where @xmath872 is the standard point - particle effective action ( [ 6.1 ] ) and where @xmath873 with @xmath874 .",
    "several claims were made in ref .",
    "@xcite : ( i ) that the extra terms ( [ 6.31 ] ) are necessary to `` encapsulate finite size properties of the sources '' , ( ii ) that they are linked to the same `` dangerous '' diagrams that were examined in fig .  6 of @xcite and fig .  [ fig1 ] above , and ( iii ) that they entail the presence of genuine ambiguities at the 3pn level which can only be fixed by a matching calculation . if these statements were correct , that would mean not only that the basic `` effacement '' property ( modulo 5pn - level `` quadrupole - type '' additional terms to the effective action ) is incorrect , but also that the recent results , @xcite and this work , fixing all 3pn - level ambiguity parameters by dr are flawed .",
    "let us , however , indicate why we think that the claims ( i ) , ( ii ) and ( iii ) made in ref .",
    "@xcite are not correct .",
    "first , we mention that the addition of curvature - coupling terms of the type indicated in ( [ 6.31 ] ) has already been considered in ref .",
    "@xcite and in appendix  a of ref .",
    "@xcite , which considered finite - size effects in tensor - scalar gravity . indeed , when gravity is partly mediated by a scalar excitation , the internal characteristics of compact objects are much less effaced than in the pure spin-2 case",
    ". in particular , the coupling to the spherical inertia moment @xmath875 can introduce extra couplings of the type of the curvature terms in ( [ 6.31 ] ) ( see @xcite ) together with several other scalar - dependent couplings .",
    "however , it was shown in @xcite that the use of suitable field redefinitions can transform away the curvature couplings ( [ 6.31 ] ) into couplings explicitly involving the gradient of the scalar field , @xmath876 . as such a term does not exist in the pure spin-2 case",
    ", one sees that ref .",
    "@xcite proves that ( [ 6.31 ] ) can be field - redefined away .",
    "indeed , a simple way to see it is to recall that the first - order effect of a field redefinition of the metric @xmath877 is to modify the effective action by terms proportional to the einstein field equations , namely @xmath878 [ to simplify , we set the light velocity @xmath879 here and below ] .",
    "conversely , the ( _ a priori _ illicit ) use of the einstein field equations _ within an action _ is equivalent to a suitably defined field redefinition @xmath880 . applying this general result to ( [ 6.30 ] )",
    "we see that the curvature coupling terms ( [ 6.31 ] ) are equivalent to @xmath881 ( where @xmath18 and @xmath882 ) modulo a field redefinition @xmath883 of the type @xmath884 \\ , \\frac{\\delta^{(d ) } ( x^{\\lambda } - y_a^{\\lambda } ( s_a))}{\\sqrt{-g } } \\ , .\\ ] ] here @xmath885 , @xmath886 , @xmath887 , @xmath888 are linear combinations of the coefficients @xmath889 , @xmath890 entering ( [ 6.31 ] ) , namely @xmath891 , @xmath892 . after using",
    ", for instance , the delta function in time , @xmath893 , to integrate over @xmath894 ( with the conclusion that @xmath895 ) , one easily sees that the result ( [ 6.32 ] ) is proportional to the @xmath896-integral of the @xmath0-dimensional delta function evaluated at a vanishing separation : @xmath897 . in dr ,",
    "such a pure contact term vanishes exactly , so that we have simply @xmath898 . [ as ref .",
    "@xcite uses also dr , we are entitled in using dr to discuss their claims . ] therefore we conclude that the proposed curvature - coupling terms ( [ 6.31 ] ) are equivalent to a field redefinition of the type ( [ 6.33 ] )",
    ". however , ( [ 6.33 ] ) is again a `` contact term '' in the sense that it vanishes outside of the world - lines , and can not therefore affect the external field generated by the world - lines that we are interested in . in conclusion",
    ", the term ( [ 6.31 ] ) can be essentially completely field - redefined away , and has no physical import .",
    "we can give another ( partial ) confirmation of this result by looking at the form of the pole that ref .",
    "@xcite claims to be associated with the diagrams in fig .",
    "6 of @xcite , or fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] here ( _ i.e. _ , diagrams ( c ) and ( d ) of fig .  7 of @xcite ) . transcribing the fourier - space result ( 53 ) of @xcite in @xmath739-space , and considering the combination that enters the leading term in the multipole moments , one finds that , according to @xcite , those dangerous diagrams are equivalent , when @xmath264 , to an effective mass - energy distribution of the type @xmath899 where @xmath900 is a ( non zero ) numerical constant and @xmath22 the laplacian .",
    "the result ( [ 6.34 ] ) is consistent with part of our analysis above . indeed , using eqs .",
    "( [ 6.7 ] ) , ( [ 6.11 ] ) , ( [ 6.16 ] ) and ( [ 6.25 ] ) , our analysis has shown that the dangerous terms in the cubically non - linear `` non compact '' contributions to @xmath453 , @xmath462 and @xmath463 are equivalent to a term in @xmath453 of the form @xmath901.\\ ] ] the equation ( [ 6.34 ] ) is consistent with the _ first _ term on the rhs of ( [ 6.35 ] ) .",
    "but , as we have shown above , this term has no physical implication ; only the _ second _ term , involving a _ dipole _ coupling @xmath902 , mattered .",
    "this confirms our conclusion that the claims ( i ) , ( ii ) and ( iii ) of @xcite are not correct because the terms they considered have no physical relevance .",
    "note also that the `` finite size '' effect ( [ 6.34 ] ) ( formally linked to a spherical inertia moment @xmath903 , as in the tensor - scalar case of @xcite ) is actually a 2pn - level term .",
    "if that term had created physical effects linked to the finite - size of the source , this would have meant that the 2.5pn equations of motion @xcite had missed some 2pn violation of the effacement properties . as a final comment",
    "let us recall that the adm - gauge calculations of @xcite never exhibited any pole . in adm - gauge",
    "all the 3pn diagrams are finite and the whole discussion of possible renormalization - group dependent quantities evaporates away .",
    "in sec .  [ secvi ] we obtained unique values for the three heretofore unknown parameters @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 , by adding to the hr calculations of the quadrupole moment of an interacting binary point - mass system the additional contributions @xmath678 coming from a dr treatment of the singularities near @xmath512 and @xmath513 . in sec .",
    "[ secvii ] we have shown that a detailed study of the structure of the singular diagrams represented in fig .  [ fig1 ] allowed one to check the values of both @xmath4 and @xmath3 ( using information about the full computation of the dipole moment in hr to check the latter ) . here",
    ", we shall complete our checks by giving an independent calculation of the third parameter @xmath5 .",
    "this calculation will be based on a full dr evaluation of the quadrupole moment of a moving isolated particle ( @xmath904 , @xmath905 ) . in another paper ,",
    "@xcite , we have already checked the value of @xmath5 within a purely @xmath41-dimensional approach , based on the physical situation of an isolated boosted schwarzschild ( exterior ) solution with mass @xmath621 ( and still with @xmath906 ) , and without use of any self - field regularization .",
    "therefore our new , dr - based , computation of @xmath5 given here can also be viewed as a further check of the consistency of dr .",
    "we thus consider the limiting case of a single particle with mass @xmath621 , moving on a straight line . in order to be able to discuss meaningfully this limiting case ,",
    "it is important not to use a center - of - mass frame for the original binary system @xmath621 , @xmath622 . indeed ,",
    "if we start from a center - of - mass frame before taking the limit @xmath907 , we shall end up with a single particle at rest and placed at the center of the coordinate frame used to compute the multipole moments . to simplify the notation",
    ", we shall suppress the index @xmath908 on the characteristics of the single particle that we consider .",
    "as in @xcite we gain also some simplification by assuming that the origin of the coordinate system ( with respect to which the particle is moving ) which is used to define the multipole moments coincides with the position of the particle at the time @xmath909 .",
    "in other words , we consider a single particle of mass @xmath910 , moving on the world - line @xmath911 .",
    "as was already used in @xcite , the limiting case @xmath912 , @xmath907 , @xmath913 of the mass - type quadrupole moment of a binary system @xmath914 , evaluated by hr in @xcite , takes the form ( at 3pn order ) @xmath915 + \\left(\\frac{232}{63}+\\frac{44}{3}\\,\\zeta\\right ) \\frac{g^2m^3}{c^6}\\,v^{\\langle i } v^{j\\rangle}\\,.\\ ] ] as we see , the @xmath5-ambiguity enters only in a term @xmath916 .",
    "we shall henceforth focus on this term and show how dr uniquely fixes its coefficient , _",
    "i.e. _ , the numerical coefficient @xmath917 in the expression @xmath918 to evaluate the coefficient @xmath917 in dr , the first step is to obtain the @xmath33-dimensional metric , _ in harmonic coordinates _ , generated by a boosted point particle .",
    "we shall first determine the metric generated by a point particle at rest and then apply lorentz invariance in @xmath33 dimensions .",
    "there are two ways of doing this .",
    "we can start from the expressions for the harmonically relaxed einstein field equations ( at 3pn order ) explicitly given in @xcite and solve them by iteration , when assuming a source given by a single delta function .",
    "another method consists in starting from the well - known @xmath33-dimensional schwarzschild solution , in schwarzschild - droste coordinates , and then look for the _ particular _ harmonic coordinates selected by the dr treatment of delta - function sources .",
    "we have used both methods and checked that they fully agree .",
    "let us indicate some details of the first , more pedestrian , approach .    in the rest frame of a single point particle",
    ", the stress - energy tensor has @xmath919 as single non - vanishing component .",
    "this yields a `` scalar '' source @xmath920 , as used in our formalism , see eq .",
    "( [ mattersources ] ) , of the form @xmath921 with @xmath922 , together with @xmath923 .",
    "the basic scalar potential @xmath477 generated by @xmath502 , @xmath924 , is then found to be @xmath925 where @xmath926/\\pi^{(d-2)/2}$ ] .",
    "the other linear potentials are easily found to vanish , @xmath927 , @xmath928 .",
    "going then to the various non - linear potentials , one finds , successively , @xmath929 , @xmath930 , @xmath931 , as well as @xmath932 .",
    "note that the vanishing of all those potentials results both from the treatment of contact terms in dr ( namely @xmath933 ) and from the special structure of einstein s equations ( the fact that @xmath474 and @xmath476 vanish is due to the special structure of some cubic non - linearities in einstein s equations ) . finally , besides @xmath477 ,",
    "the only non - vanishing potentials are @xmath479 and @xmath934 , which are determined by solving              note that a remarkable simplification occurred in the expression ( [ 7.11 ] ) of the spatial gothic metric .",
    "indeed , we see form ( [ 7.4 ] ) that @xmath942 is proportional to @xmath943 and therefore that @xmath944 while @xmath945 .",
    "the result ( [ 7.11 ] ) shows that @xmath946 + \\mathcal{o}[(gm / c^2)^4 ] + \\cdots$ ] .",
    "the point is that there are no terms @xmath947 in the spatial gothic metric .",
    "one can even prove , more generally , that the spatial structure of einstein s equations is such that @xmath948 ( for a particle at rest ) contains only _ even _ powers of @xmath943 .",
    "the only component of the gothic metric which contains _ odd _ powers of @xmath943 , and in particular @xmath949 , is the time - time component @xmath489 , eq .",
    "( [ 7.10 ] ) .    by explicitly solving eq .",
    "( [ 7.5 ] ) , we find , in @xmath0 dimensions , @xmath950.\\ ] ] inserting this result in the rhs of ( [ 7.6 ] ) then allows one to solve for @xmath473 , in any dimension @xmath0 , and we find @xmath951 then , from eq .",
    "( [ 7.10 - 11 ] ) we get , still in the rest frame : @xmath952 where @xmath953 , @xmath179 and @xmath954 can be expressed in terms of @xmath942 and admit expansions of the type      where , as said above , @xmath179 and @xmath954 contain only _ even _ powers of @xmath942 .",
    "the @xmath0-dependent numerical coefficients @xmath956 , @xmath957 , @xmath958 , @xmath959 and @xmath960 can be read off the results ( [ 7.4 ] ) and ( [ 7.10 - 11])([7.13 ] ) above .",
    "it is then easy to `` boost '' the metric ( [ 7.14 ] ) to a moving frame .",
    "it suffices to write it as @xmath961 where @xmath962 is the @xmath33-velocity of the particle , and @xmath963 the unit radial @xmath33-vector orthogonal to the world - line .",
    ", @xmath964 , @xmath965 , and @xmath966 .",
    "] as the mass @xmath910 enters only through @xmath967 , we see immediately from ( [ 7.18 ] ) that , in the `` laboratory frame '' where the point particle is moving , the only term in the gothic metric ( [ 7.18 ] ) which is cubic in @xmath968 is @xmath969 the explicit value of the coefficient @xmath958 in ( [ 7.19 ] ) is found to be @xmath970.\\ ] ] when @xmath971 , one finds @xmath972.\\ ] ] finally , to obtain ( [ 7.19 ] ) in the lab - frame , we need to re - express the rest - frame result ( [ 7.14 ] ) for @xmath477 in terms of lab - frame quantities .",
    "this is simply done by saying that the rest - frame radial distance @xmath126 entering ( [ 7.4 ] ) can be invariantly characterized as the orthogonal distance @xmath973 between the world - line and the field point . in any frame , @xmath973 is given by @xmath974 where @xmath975 is _ any _ point on the world - line ( @xmath975 does not need to be such that @xmath976 be orthogonal to @xmath962 ) . finally , we get for the part of the gothic metric deviation @xmath977 which is cubic in @xmath978 , @xmath979 where @xmath980 , @xmath981 and @xmath982 where @xmath983 is the point on the world - line which is lab - synchronous with the field point ( at the same time @xmath984 ) .",
    "we have focused here on the terms cubic in @xmath968 because , as indicated in ( [ 7.1])([7.2 ] ) , we are only interested in computing the coefficient @xmath917 appearing in front of the cubic term of ( [ 7.2 ] ) .",
    "we need now to use the _ definition _ of the mass quadrupole moment @xmath381 , which is given by eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) , where the rhs is expressed in terms of the pn expansion of @xmath985 . introducing , as in ( [ sigma ] ) above",
    ", the notation @xmath986/c^2 $ ] , @xmath987 , @xmath988 , we finally obtained the following @xmath0-dimensional expressions for the cubic terms in these various effective sources :      where @xmath990 so that we have the expansion @xmath991 here @xmath992 is the usual , lab - instantaneous , distance between the field point @xmath510 and the particle @xmath993 , and @xmath994 .",
    "we have re - installed here the index @xmath908 to distinguish the radial distance to the particle , @xmath995 , from the radial distance to the origin of the lab - frame coordinate system , everywhere denoted as @xmath996 .",
    "when inserting the explicit expressions ( [ 7.25 ] ) in the definition of the quadrupole moment , one ends up with a sum of @xmath0-dimensional integrals whose integrands contain several types of factors : an overall factor @xmath997 , various multipolar factors @xmath998 , together with various spatial derivatives of @xmath999 .",
    "we use @xmath1000 to replace time derivatives acting on the @xmath453 s by space derivatives . by separating the quadrupole moment in several contributions , as is eq .",
    "( [ ilexpr2 ] ) above , one easily checks that the leading @xmath1001 contribution coming from replacing @xmath1002 is @xmath754 and gives a vanishing contribution ( after taking the @xmath0-modified finite part ) .",
    "then it takes more work to check that the @xmath1003 contribution @xmath757 coming from the time derivative of @xmath1004 also gives a vanishing contribution .",
    "one is then left to evaluating an integral of the type @xmath1005 the dependence on @xmath226 of the global factor ( not displayed here ) does not import for our present calculation . on",
    "the contrary , the relative coefficients @xmath1006 and @xmath1007 of the two terms are crucial , as there will occur below a cancellation between their lowest order contributions .",
    "the trick to compute eq .",
    "( [ 7.27 ] ) ( for a finite value of @xmath179 ) is to express it , after using some integration by parts , in terms of parametric derivatives of `` riesz integrals '' .",
    "an ( euclidean ) riesz integral in any dimension @xmath0 is the integral @xmath1008 where the numerical coefficient @xmath1009 is equal to @xmath1010 we find that we can express ( [ 7.27 ] ) as being proportional to @xmath1011 here , we have introduced , as extra parameter , the position @xmath1012 of the origin used to define the multipole moments . up to now we have simply taken @xmath1013 , but one could have defined from the start the multipole moments with factors of the type @xmath1014 . inserting all needed factors , and explicitly evaluating the derivatives appearing in ( [ 7.29 ] ) , we end up with a final answer of the type @xmath1015 , _",
    "i.e. _ , of the form expected from eq .",
    "( [ 7.2 ] ) , with a numerical coefficient given , after appropriate expansion , by @xmath1016,\\ ] ] where the ellipsis denote terms of higher order in @xmath226 and/or @xmath179 that do not contribute .",
    "we explicitly exhibit the near - final form ( [ 7.30 ] ) to emphasize the subtle nature of the determination of @xmath917 .",
    "the result is proportional to @xmath179 , which will ultimately be analytically continued to zero , so that one might _ a priori _ believe that @xmath917 will vanish when @xmath185 .",
    "however , this is not so because @xmath917 also contains the shifted pole @xmath1017 .",
    "in addition , when @xmath179 is non zero , ( [ 7.30 ] ) also exhibits a pole @xmath600 . as we explained above , the mpm formalism ( and its subsequent pn re - expansion ) imposes a specific finite part operation fp to be applied to all multipole moments .",
    "it consists in first subtracting the shifted pole terms and then in taking the limit @xmath185 ( see sec .  [ seciiia ] ) .",
    "for instance , in the case of a simple pole of the form @xmath1018 , one must subtract @xmath1019 before taking @xmath185 , which then leads to the finite part @xmath1020/(-2\\varepsilon)$ ] . applying this to ( [ 7.30 ] ) yields the final result @xmath1021 which is exactly the same result as found with an independent surface - integral evaluation @xcite . comparing this value to the last term on the rhs of eq .",
    "( [ 7.1 ] ) , we then conclude that @xmath5 is uniquely fixed to the value @xmath1022 in full agreement with our full two - body dr results in ( [ resamb ] ) above , and with the regularization - free calculations of ref .",
    "@xcite .    two of us ( l.b . and b.r.i . ) would like to thank the indo - french collaboration ( ifcpar ) under which this work has been carried out .",
    "b.r.i . thanks ihes for hospitality at different stages of the work .",
    "the calculations reported in this paper have been done with the help of the software _"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> dimensional regularization is applied to the computation of the gravitational wave field generated by compact binaries at the third post - newtonian ( 3pn ) approximation . </S>",
    "<S> we generalize the wave generation formalism from isolated post - newtonian matter systems to @xmath0 spatial dimensions , and apply it to point masses ( without spins ) , modelled by delta - function singularities . </S>",
    "<S> we find that the quadrupole moment of point - particle binaries in harmonic coordinates contains a pole when @xmath1 at the 3pn order . </S>",
    "<S> it is proved that the pole can be renormalized away by means of the same shifts of the particle world - lines as in our recent derivation of the 3pn equations of motion . </S>",
    "<S> the resulting renormalized ( finite when @xmath2 ) quadrupole moment leads to unique values for the ambiguity parameters @xmath3 , @xmath4 and @xmath5 , which were introduced in previous computations using hadamard s regularization . </S>",
    "<S> several checks of these values are presented . </S>",
    "<S> these results complete the derivation of the gravitational waves emitted by inspiralling compact binaries up to the 3.5pn level of accuracy which is needed for detection and analysis of the signals in the gravitational - wave antennas ligo / virgo and lisa . </S>"
  ]
}
